100*(mana in from VT) / (shadow damage out * 0.05)

E.G., on the last Gorefiend, I dealt 264718 shadow damage and regenned 13,021 mana via VT. That's 98% uptime during damage. Obviously, the goal should be 100% damage uptime.

#623SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Elerion
vanskater:
Differences like that in DPS time on Illidan is most likely down to how you handle the demon form in P3 forward. Usually you can keep dots up on Illidan throughout that entire phase if you are smart with refreshes and movement.

Refresh dots on Illidan before the transition to demon
Move to a safe spot for the first explosion
After explosion First Aid, refresh VT and run back before demon spawn
Once demons spawn dps them until they are obviously controlled, then refresh dots on Illidan
You might even throw in a few MBs on Illidan if you feel safe with regards to threat

Note that this probably isn't beneficial to the raid as a whole due to slightly increased risk, but it does allow you to keep the 96% dps time of your #1 priest. I wouldn't do it before Illidan is truly on farm since it's not really a dps encounter, but at the point you are, you can start having fun and trying to win.

Demon phase dots and dual dotting Flames are the reasons shadow priests are able to top damage meters on Illidan. Use it for what it's worth.

Aside from that, your MB hit number is way too low. A 15 minute Illidan kill should let you do 40+ Mind Blasts.

#635SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3heel
Every Shadow Priest should now want to wear all of the following haste items in place of currently optimal gear:

[Loop of Cursed Bones]
[Bracers of Nimble Thought]
[Waistwrap of Infinity]
[Ring of Ancient Knowledge]
[Ring of Ancient Knowledge]
[The Skull of Gul'dan] (this and [Hex Shrunken Head] are now undoubtedly the two best trinkets)
[Zhar'doom, Greatstaff of the Devourer]

This setup is the best way to give you the 197 haste you need to avoid GCD clipping. Who knows, though - maybe haste is now worth it all the way up to 250 or 300 or something. In any case, getting to 197 haste is now absolutely worth it and these seven items should be on the top of any Shadow Priest's wishlist.

#640SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Evilpig
Originally Posted by heel
If you have access to everything, you absolutely want to shoot for a minimum of 197.
I'm not so sure about that... Currently you need 197 to fit 2 hasted flays in the 5.5mb cooldown, but that's because the GCD causes you to have dead time between the time your first MB cast ends and your first MF cast begins. If the changes to haste in 2.4 result in you actually being able to start your MF at the end of your MB cast, you'd only need 143. To clarify: I'm not suggesting that you wouldn't want to stack large amounts of haste, just that I don't think 197 will be a magical number anymore.
Last edited by Evilpig : 02/01/08 at 3:37 PM.
#641SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3cheebamonkey
The big difference now is that untill someone gets to 33% haste all our spells scale exactly the same with haste as MF use to meaning haste is our best stat like it is for pretty much every other caster. What's going to be important now is maximizing our highest dps spells usage which will always be non MF spells. Meaning we should still be shooting for 5.5 second CD MB's and 12 second CD SWD as often as possible. Anything else is just trying to squeeze more in between those two.

#647SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3cheebamonkey
If we are still using the 5.5 second MB rotation then the only way you can increase your dps via haste rating while holding the cycle is to increase from 143 to 416 (the haste required to fit 5 GCD's in between MB's as oposed to 4 GCD's like more people are doing). Anywhere in between and you're just pushing your MB's back or wasting haste points. Basically if we want to stack haste we will probably have to do a lot more thinking about the best rotation we can manage and oportunity costs of casting MF vs getting off a MB/SWD that much earlier.
#648SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Tymir
At this point I am wondering if haste will be able to reduce the GCD on instant cast spells, it will be interesting to see how blues handle this issue.
#649SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Originally Posted by Snowy
Are the badge pants REALLY crappy now though? If 1 point of spell haste becomes better than 1 point of spell damage, then those badge pants will be over 100 damage in essence. Personally, it's not an item on my radar because I want 4 pc T6 and Shahraz legs (Kaz'Rogal was a bitch) but for a spriest gearing up, they look far more attractive now.
There's also mantle of nimble thought and 4T6 (ie. including the pants). I have Shahraz legs as well, because they are almost as good as Kaz'rogal's legs for me but far inferior for mages. If you want to keep 4 piece bonus (and you do, until sunwell), then your options for shoulders + pants are:

[Mantle of Nimble Thought] + [Leggings of Absolution] = 38 Haste + 123 Damage
[Shoulderpads of Absolution] + [Pantaloons of Arcane Annihilation] = 45 Haste + 127 Damage
[Shoulderpads of Absolution] + [Leggings of Devastation] = 169 damage

I counted 6 crit rating as 1 haste and ignored hit rating, by the way. And every slot gets a spinel.

So is it worth trading 42 damage for 45 haste? It seems like the answer is a resounding, "Yes!"

#650SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3chase
Originally Posted by cheebamonkey
I believe he said this because it would take 514 haste to make a 1.5 second spell cast in 1 second using current haste rating conversions.
As I understood it:

15.7 spell haste = 1% haste

Hasted effect on cast time can be worked out as:
talented cast time / (1 + percent haste) = new cast time

So to get a 1.5 second spell to cast in 1 second:

1.5/(1+x)=1
x=.5=50% haste=50*15.7=785 spell haste

Pretty sure this is correct. Not sure where 514 comes from. (~604 spell haste + lust/heroism = 1 sec cast)
#651SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Originally Posted by chase
As I understood it:

15.7 spell haste = 1% haste

Hasted effect on cast time can be worked out as:
talented cast time / (1 + percent haste) = new cast time

So to get a 1.5 second spell to cast in 1 second:

1.5/(1+x)=1
x=.5=50% haste=50*15.7=785 spell haste

Pretty sure this is correct. Not sure where 514 comes from. (~604 spell haste + lust/heroism = 1 sec cast)
It comes from bad math. 514 haste rating is 33% haste. If you use the incorrect formula of:

cast time = old cast time * (1 - haste)

Then you get 1.5 * (1 - 1/3) = 1.5 * 2/3 = 1.0.
#652SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3cheebamonkey
yeah, it should be 785 haste not 514
#653SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Arrian
Originally Posted by cheebamonkey
The big difference now is that untill someone gets to 33% haste all our spells scale exactly the same with haste as MF use to meaning haste is our best stat like it is for pretty much every other caster.
No, they won't.

33% haste would knock a 1.5 second cast MB down to 1 second, true. But that means you can cast MB once every 6.5 seconds rather than once every 7 seconds. 1-6.5/7 = about a 7% DPS increase on MB over the course of a fight.

It has 0 effect on Shadow Word Pain, just letting the following spell be cast a bit sooner.

It only effects the second VT you cast, all others are just chained to the previous giving you 0.5 seconds more VT time regardless of the fight length.

It has 0 effect on how often you can cast Shadow Word: Death though it lets you cast the spell after SW: Death faster.

The effect on Mind Flay has not changed.

We won't begin to scale linearly with haste the way locks do, or nearly linearly the way mages do. The biggest determinant of our DPS is how often we can cast our spells not how long it takes to cast our spells like most other casters.

I'm skeptical that this will be a significant enough change to make haste stacking significantly better for us than it is now.
#654SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Elegen
Originally Posted by Arrian
The effect on Mind Flay has not changed.
With troll berserking, bloodlust, skull, and haste gear I can hit around 1.2-1.4s MFs. With a focus gem proc my MF is 1.33s normally, or under 1s with various combinations of the aforementioned buffs. So under certain circumstances my MF can drop below 1.5s. If that's with the super buff scenario then I can do it for 10 seconds consecutively and actually put out more DPS with MF than MB. Unfortunately most people did not roll the super troll race.
#655SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
Originally Posted by Arrian
It only effects the second VT you cast, all others are just chained to the previous giving you 0.5 seconds more VT time regardless of the fight length.
Not true. It gives you 0.5 seconds more *casting* time between VTs, which is a significant benefit. Same is true for MB and Death; you get slightly more cast time potentially spent on filling with flay, as well as a flay DPS boost.

Think of it this way, with a 1s GCD and 50% haste to get you there, an initial sequence looks something like.

-1.0 VT starts casting
0.0 VT casts, GCD Ends
0.0 SWP casts
1.0 GCD ends
1.0 MB starts casting
2.0 MB casts, GCD ends
2.0 SWD casts
3.0 GCD ends
3.0 MF casts
4.0 GCD ends
5.0 MF finishes casting
5.0 MF casts
6.0 GCD ends
7.0 MF end
7.0-7.5 ?deadtime? in reality, probably lag eliminates this
7.5 MB cooldown ends
7.5 MB starts casting
8.5 MB casts, GCD ends
8.5 MF casts
9.5 GCD ends
10.5 MF ends
10.5 MF casts
11.5 GCD ends
12.5 MF ends
12.5 MF casts
13.5 GCD ends
14.0 SWD cooldown ends, MB cooldown ends
14.0 VT casts, clipping MF after 2 ticks

That's 2 mindblasts, 1 SWD, 4.66 MFs, and SWP/VT uptime. Compared to the 1.5s GCD, where you wouldn't even get 4 full MFs in that sequence, it's a significant benefit. I'll work on the sim at some point soon to reflect this change; I expect it to show haste getting a significant increase, especially once I implement MF clipping.
#656SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Elegen
I thought of one other benefit as well. This may open up the opportunity to increase DPS by cutting off MF after 1 tick to recast a higher DPS spell since you now should have 0.66 seconds before your second tick instead of 0.5 given 199 spell haste. At 0.66s you are losing a smaller portion of potential DPS time which might offset it enough. I can't wrap my head around the exact numbers right now because my mind is totally burned out from work. My quick calculation tells me the following spell will only have to average around 1200 DPS or higher given an average tick of 800 for your MF.
#657SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
Originally Posted by Elegen
I thought of one other benefit as well. This may open up the opportunity to increase DPS by cutting off MF after 1 tick to recast a higher DPS spell since you now should have 0.66 seconds before your second tick instead of 0.5 given 199 spell haste. At 0.66s you are losing a smaller portion of potential DPS time which might offset it enough. I can't wrap my head around the exact numbers right now because my mind is totally burned out from work. My quick calculation tells me the following spell will only have to average around 1200 DPS or higher given an average tick of 800 for your MF.
At 199 haste (12.6% haste), Mind Flay lasts 2.66 seconds, and ticks at 0.885, 1.77, and 2.66 seconds. The GCD would be 1.33 seconds.

Did you mean 0.44 to the next tick not .66?
#658SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Elegen
With the GCD at 1.5s the order would go tick one at 1s, GCD expires at 1.5s, tick two at 2s. With 199 haste it would be Tick 1 at 0.8866s, GCD up at 1.33s, tick 2 at 1.7733s, so yeah, 0.44s is right. I'm so used to the GCD not scaling that I didn't even think about the whole proportion shrinking in relation to time. I guess the number is really closer to an 1800 relative DPS loss considering the correct equation. It's been hard couple weeks at work. I can't think strait.
#659SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Jubling
Here's some napkin math to try and find how much dps one point of haste rating is. I'm not sure if it's correct and it ignores spell rotation timings like the ones discussed in the previous posts, so it'll probably only be right for specific amounts of haste that makes them line up.

In a one minute fight 1% spellhaste would give another 60 - (60 / 1,01) = 0,59 seconds to cast spells in, maybe a bit less since you don't really spend all 60 seconds casting due to latency and reaction time. (And assuming you stay below the 1 second GCD cap which seems impossible to reach).

So that's another 0,59 * your dps damage over 60 seconds for 15,7 rating. If we assume a base dps of around 400 with 0 spellpower and 1 spellpower = +0,5 dps (which seems reasonable from my Dr. Boom testing) we get this for 1200 spellpower:

((60 - (60 / 1,01)) * (400 + (1 200 / 2))) / 60 = 9,9 extra dps for 15,7 rating, meaning 1 spell haste rating = +0,63 dps or 1 spell haste rating = 1,26 spellpower.

Is this on the right track or am I too tired to theorycraft properly?
Last edited by Jubling : 02/01/08 at 10:06 PM.
#660SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Lazare
Napkin math attempt:

A shadow priest might spend half a fight casting MF, so over a 300s fight you might spend 150s casting MF, and 150s casting everything else.

Haste has two effects:
  1. It lets you spend less time casting everything else.
  2. It lets you pack more MFs in per minute.

393 spell haste should be enough for 25% haste, so your "everything else" period goes from 150s to (150/(1 + 25%)) = 120s, giving you an extra 30s of MF time. Further, in the 180s of MF time you can pack in (180*(1+25%)) = 225s worth of unhasted MF.

So, in a 300s fight with 25% haste you gain 225 - 150 = 75s worth of unhasted MF spam, which is 25% of the fight time. More generally, you always will gain X% of total fight length in MF spam, where X is your haste %.

If your MF does 500 dps, then for 25% haste and a 300s fight you gain an extra 25%*300*500 = 37.5k damage, which works out to an extra 125 dps over the fight. More generally, if you have X% haste and a Y dps unhasted MF, you should see an increase of X*Y dps for the entire fight.

Caveats: Haste may mess up your spell rotations and add dead time, or improve them and remove it. Probably more the former than the latter, but for a long run average, X% haste giving you extra dps equal to X% of your unhasted MF dps seems a good approximation...if my napkin math is even vaguely correct.
#661SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3galzohar
As long as you have 5/5 imp MB haste will at least not mess up your MB rotation if you have less haste than what is needed for 2.75s MF. Anything more and I can't see how you can benefit much as often you'll find yourself in a situation where you have just cast MB MF MF and are now stuck with MB/SWD on cooldown and nothing to refresh. Of corse this will not *always* be the case, so more haste is always better, but I expect it to greatly drop in value once you drop your MFs under 2.75s.
#662SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3dreadai
Doesn't this discussion of GCD become somewhat irrelevant in the light of the preliminary 2.4 notes? With haste also acting to reduce the GCD, MSD will become exponentially more powerful, other spells than MF can be used without 'wasting' the proc.

I'm quite excited (nerdgasm) about the new possibilities of the class with the proposed chages.
#663SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Balkoth

Considering a MB or VT consumed with the proc will be under 1 second, even without any haste gear, you're still wasting it to come extent. Not to mention it seems that with 0 spell haste you'll still have a 1.5 second GCD, meaning it's completely wasted, I suppose.
#664SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3cheebamonkey
I've been thinking about it and I really don't think it will be anymore benificial to go past 2.75 second MF's asside from making up for latency. To the best of my knowledge we get our maximum dps while using a 5/5 Imp MB every cooldown. That means with the new haste rating the cycle is going to be 6.875 seconds long meaning 13.75 seconds for every two cycles. So if you are employing a MB, MF, MF, MB, MF, VT, SWD cycle you are delaying your SWD by only 1.75 seconds and are cutting off your last tick of VT 1.75 seconds in. Adding any more haste will effectively make your SWD and MB downtime greater which one could argue would be balanced by more MF time however adding more SP will no questions asked increase your dps. The only other way I can think of to come up with another rotation that fits in with this one requires you to do:

MB, MF(2 ticks), MF(2 ticks), MF (Full), MB, MF(2 ticks), MF(2 ticks), VT, SWD

Where you use two ticks so you can get around the problem of trying to get in 1 extra tick and the global cooldown still being up. However this would require at least 27.23% haste or 430 haste rating to do. Which I believe may be possible but would require every piece of haste gear currently in the game.
#665SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Crepusculu
The spellhaste announced change is very interesting.

I went through doing some frequency charts assuming perfect cooldowns and casting (lag creates too much varitation)
I'd like to share some of the values I got for the per-point values


Using ~1300+ shadow
Stat type => flayspam dps - cooldown dps

+1 damage => 0.21 - 0.40
+1 crit rating => 0.00 - 0.11
+1 hit rating => 0.37 - 0.81 (zero when capped)
+1 haste rating => 0.08 - 0.25


While still not as superior as spell damage, Blizzard's itemization formula favors the splitting between two stats. Thus spell haste fills that position. The most surprising part is that my data suggests that spell haste only GAINS dps for the least amount of mindflaying and LOSES dps when you exclusively cast mindflay.

Do these figures look reasonable?
#666SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Originally Posted by Crepusculu
The spellhaste announced change is very interesting.

I went through doing some frequency charts assuming perfect cooldowns and casting (lag creates too much varitation)
I'd like to share some of the values I got for the per-point values


Using ~1300+ shadow
Stat type => flayspam dps - cooldown dps

+1 damage => 0.21 - 0.40
+1 crit rating => 0.00 - 0.11
+1 hit rating => 0.37 - 0.81 (zero when capped)
+1 haste rating => 0.08 - 0.25


While still not as superior as spell damage, Blizzard's itemization formula favors the splitting between two stats. Thus spell haste fills that position. The most surprising part is that my data suggests that spell haste only GAINS dps for the least amount of mindflaying and LOSES dps when you exclusively cast mindflay.

Do these figures look reasonable?
How exactly did you come up with these numbers? In particular, how was hit rating modeled? Getting a resist on your mind flay seriously messes up cycles because it only costs 1.5 seconds when you were planning on spending 3 seconds casting it, so accounting for that effect is not trivial.

Just eyeballing the numbers, the basic ratio of crit to damage is around 6:1 which is what your estimate says as well. For haste BEFORE the GCD change, there were three different estimates:

- Me: 1 haste = .5 to .6 damage
- Nikitabanana: 1 haste = 1 damage or better
- Simulation: 1 haste = .8 to 1.0 damage (sorry, forgot who ran this)

Your numbers estimate .54 damage, which matches up with the lowest estimate (mine) before this change was announced. The ballpark estimate is that haste is now twice as good as before, so your haste estimate seems off by an order of magnitude.

Another thing to keep in mind is that trading 1 haste rating for X damage is not the same as trading 100 haste rating for 100*X damage, because of how haste can help or hinder cycles. The second trade might be better or it might be worse-- we really don't know. So I'm curious how the haste number was computed as well.
#667SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Crepusculu
I'll be quite honest: I believe many of these posts are overvaluing haste by a large margin. My theory numbers showed haste was horrible all the way to patch 2.3, but I'm now picking up pieces to run some real live tests (at 144 rating)



The model takes for granted that spells must be casted in units and operates the assumption that you can find the perfect cycle/priority to keep all spells on cooldown. It's easier this way since it provides a hard limit.

Works like this:

haste_rating/( 10 *(70+12)/53) = haste_multiplier
casttime = base_casttime/(1+haste_multiplier)
spell_frequency_casttime = 1/(spell_cooldown)*casttime
*Note* spell_cooldown is the duration of the dot or hard cooldown, and mindblast has an extra +casttime
You sum up all frequencies except for mindflay, which then fills the frequency sum to reach 1.
Numbers for mindflay range from 0.51 up to 0.83 (which is a simple VT-pain-flay cycle)

From this point, we know the time spent casting each spell, so we simply calculate casting dps
dpct = (base_damage + spell_bonus*coof)*(1*(1-critrate)+1.5*(critrate))*hitrate*collective_multipliers*(1-natural_boss_mirigration) / casttime
The multipliers I used were shadow form, darkness, weaving, misery, CoS (not improved), and 40% uptime on Imp SB, which is 1.73. Hit rating is taken for granted as a flat modifier as the mindflay resist rate(the only thing gains time) in the overall scheme of things is 0.5%, which gives an improvement of less than 2dps. I considered it too trivial for the work required to calculate. And remember, I'm running the formulas based on FREQUENCIES, not cycles. These numbers should represent the ideal cycle. It's the casters responsibility to improvise.

After you have the frequencies and damage per casttime, just multiply.


Perhaps you would want to play around with the excel sheet? (I would need some hosting service though, if you know of any) Your other simulation numbers probably have set up a more ideal raiding setup. I am more concerned with the comparison ratios between each stat, so I set up a more typical run of the mill raid. The whole purpose of the exercise was to find the better equipment, not necessarily make absolutes (every other fight seems to change dps output anyways).
#668SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Elerion
Originally Posted by tedv
There's also mantle of nimble thought and 4T6 (ie. including the pants). I have Shahraz legs as well, because they are almost as good as Kaz'rogal's legs for me but far inferior for mages. If you want to keep 4 piece bonus (and you do, until sunwell), then your options for shoulders + pants are:

[Mantle of Nimble Thought] + [Leggings of Absolution] = 38 Haste + 123 Damage
[Shoulderpads of Absolution] + [Pantaloons of Arcane Annihilation] = 45 Haste + 127 Damage
[Shoulderpads of Absolution] + [Leggings of Devastation] = 169 damage

I counted 6 crit rating as 1 haste and ignored hit rating, by the way. And every slot gets a spinel.

So is it worth trading 42 damage for 45 haste? It seems like the answer is a resounding, "Yes!"
[Leggings of Channeled Elements] + 4pT6 remains the best. Crit has some value, as well as spirit given IDS.

So it seems like the badge legs win out regardless, unless you really need the hit rating from channeled elements for some reason.

#671SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
Well, it isn't perfect, but it seems to give mostly rational results, so you can play with the code if you have MATLAB.

Index of /wow/hastelab

I will note, it handles some things vaguely incorrectly for ease of coding. DoTs are treated as nukes with long cooldowns, for example, and resists are coded in as a damage loss, so you don't get the MF resist benefit. Procs are not handled at all, nor do I intend for them to be, nor is bloodlust dealt with (you could easily handle bloodlust cycles by changing the haste value you feed it.) There are internal flags for 2/4T6 and patch 2.4; by default, all three are currently enabled.

Some interesting results I've gotten so far:

- Haste is ~1:1 with damage, but not as linear - damage is a linear gain, while haste's value changes over time.
- Waiting for cooldowns/dot expiration has a very small effect on your DPS, and depending on the priority you use, may have no effect.
- There are specific values of haste which have a negative effect on the queueing logic I'm using, such that you lose DPS by increasing haste. I have no idea why. The 'waiting' logic I added mitigates this, assuming the right wait time. The right wait time is variable.
#672SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3lightstrike
How do you explain those gaps on the graph at 100 and 250 haste? It doesn't make sense that going past 250 haste while keeping the same spell damage is a dps loss...

I'd also expect haste to have different value at different spell damage levels, and your graph basically shows the same 7 lines, offset by the extra spell damage, which I find odd; intuitively, the more spell damage the better haste would become...
#673SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
Originally Posted by lightstrike
How do you explain those gaps on the graph at 100 and 250 haste? It doesn't make sense that going past 250 haste while keeping the same spell damage is a dps loss...

I'd also expect haste to have different value at different spell damage levels, and your graph basically shows the same 7 lines, offset by the extra spell damage, which I find odd; intuitively, the more spell damage the better haste would become...
They're points where the mindblast cooldown lowers such that the simulator (which does not clip flays) selects to flay instead of waiting for a mindblast. The simulator settings that provided the graphic used a 0 wait queue. It also did not incorporate the 2.4 GCD lowering. As such, I don't find either the dips or the independence of haste's benefit vs. +dmg to be surprising. After all, haste is essentially only a significant benefit on MF right now, with a minor MB benefit - as such, the nonlinear varying with +dmg shouldn't be visible on a graph at that scale. The simulation is provided; feel free to run it with your own settings.

Also, if you use queues with waiting, those dips are no longer there.

E.G. (haste, waittime, DPS triplets)

245,0.00: 1252
255,0.00: 1215
245,0.55: 1225
255,1.35: 1237

Finally, the graph is from an older version of the simulator, so don't put too much faith into it. I was more providing the link to the code so that people could look into it; I don't really care about what you think about the graph. I'm more interested in people with commentary on the simulation.
#674SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
to elaborate on why haste is not particularly nonlinear with +dmg:

We aren't destro locks or mages. Our DoTs, which are essentially unaffected by haste, compose a significant portion of our DPS and gain linearly from +dmg. Our nukes are also almost unaffected by haste. Once you've established these components as nearly independent of haste, the only source of potential nonlinearity is seen in MF. MF is ~25-30% of our DPS. The nonlinearity you're trying to see in a low resolution graph is going to be invisible.
#675SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Nenormalen
Originally Posted by lightstrike
How do you explain those gaps on the graph at 100 and 250 haste? It doesn't make sense that going past 250 haste while keeping the same spell damage is a dps loss...

I'd also expect haste to have different value at different spell damage levels, and your graph basically shows the same 7 lines, offset by the extra spell damage, which I find odd; intuitively, the more spell damage the better haste would become...
Haste would be perfect if it were taking place in continuous time. However, in wow, the decisions and gameplay are made in a discrete time setting.
As you know, in a DPS cycle, there are some shifty moments where you have 0.5 seconds for example before MB and you are faced with the decision to either cast a full mindflay, clip MF after 1 tick, clip MF after 2 ticks or just wait 0.5 seconds and cast MB.
When you have some haste, these gap are reduced, but they are not the same during the cycle. The first might be 0.4, some next might be 0.2 and so on.
Let's look at the case of 0.2 seconds. As you add more haste, this gap will go to 0 at some point. All good so far. As you add a little more haste, however, a spell will shift in the cycle prior to mindblast (as if the gap has become -0.1 seconds), leaving you with a new gap, of perhaps 0.9 seconds.
So even though you added that last amount of haste, here you will be forced to take again a low dps route, for at least a GCD amount of time, lowering your dps significantly. This should be more self-explanatory in a simulation where you can see the actual cycles for various levels of haste, compare the dps, and set various decision making rules regarding what to do in case of a cooldown gap.

Haste being linear with respect to spell dmg is a bit odd though, that's true.
#676SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3lightstrike
Originally Posted by Kalman
They're points where the mindblast cooldown lowers such that the simulator (which does not clip flays) selects to flay instead of waiting for a mindblast. It also did not incorporate the 2.4 GCD lowering. As such, I don't find either the dips or the independence of haste's benefit vs. +dmg to be surprising.
I'm sorry I didn't know about these facts. I assumed the graph to be generated with the current code, implementing the 2.4 change, included for those of us without matlab; that's why I found those gaps surprising... I assumed too much, it seems...

Could you maybe run a simulation with the current code and provide us with an up-to-date graph?

#681SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Goatharder
The thing that's always bothered me about gearing for haste rating is simply the artificial limitation VT puts on the situation. If you assume you're casting VT every 15 seconds (for ideal uptime), then the benifit from haste is lessened from an "over the fight" style benifit to "within the 'rotation'" benifit. (I only use the word rotation simply because it's a convenient word, not because I believe there is a rotation involved at all.)

Assuming for a minute that you have 3% haste, you would expect to see 3% more mindflay DPS assuming you filled all the 'extra' time given with flays. However, within the 15 second window the benifit from haste is so minimal that you wouldn't be able to even see another tick of flays, thus preventing you from actually seeing a DPS benifit.

00:00 VT
01:30 MB
03:00 Flay
06:00 Flay
09:00 MB
10:30 SW: D
12:00 Flay
15:00 VT

With the above, ideal setup (SW:P before the VT, SW: D and MB off CD), you cannot move the VT. Within the 15 seconds, in order to get an extra second (and thus an extra flay tick), you would need to shave off 1/3rd of a second from a flay (post 2.4, 1/4th a second off flay and 1/12th a second off MB/SW: D). To me, this seems like benifit from haste would follow more of a step progression than a linear (or semi-linear) progression of benifit. I.E., no benifit up until X value, then no more benifit until 2X value.

I know that it seems like a very simplistic way of looking at things, but with the 15 second limitation imposed by VT, small benifits fail to add up over time simply because they don't provide more casts without scads of it(which is where the real benifit of haste comes from). All of the above assumes no lag, of course, and I'm looking to pick up a few of the better haste pieces simply to overcome my 120 or so ping times, but since lag issues would occur at each 'step', it seems that it's more of a shift than a real counter to the above. I just fail to see how improving the DPS of individual mindflay casts helps your overall DPS if you're not actually dealing more damage over the course of a boss fight.

Is there anything that I'm directly missing by the above? Something that I haven't looked at in depth is people becoming more lax with VT for the sake of more DPS, but I'm convinced that my role in the raid is never sacrificing group mana regen for the sake of higher DPS, which may be a misconception on my part. I've seen a lot of math that breaks down spell usage and judges the benifit from haste that way, but would love to see an ideal representation that shows an increase in DPS due to a smallish amount of haste (say...4% haste, compared to the exact same gear pre-haste) in a mapped out way. I will start to work on it myself, but my handiwork with excel/calc isn't too hot.

#684SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3galzohar
Not to mention only using MB when SWD is almost up is a noticeable drop in DPS, although I can see why you'd do that if you're having mana issues (but then again why 5/5 imp MB?). You're leaving MB open for a lot more than 1-2 seconds.

As for haste and VT, seems like a very viable point IF VT is actually that important that you can't lose any of it, as if you could you'd get to the point where you're supposed to VT but don't want to clip it and thus use a different spell first and then VT - which may or may not be a dps loss and will affect the benefit of haste (if any). While "forcing" VT every 15 seconds regardless is probably the right thing, I wouldn't jump to assume it without going over the numbers first and checking if delaying VT by a little is worth some flay gain (or better, earlier MB/SWD if they just came up). Not that simple to figure out but if the end result is that you should always refresh VT when it runs out even if that means waiting then haste becomes useless, at least in small amounts.
#685SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Lazare
Haste and VT:

If you assume that VT must be cast every 15s no matter what, then you've reduced your choices to a recurring "how can I do the most DPS in the next 15s of dead time?" In that case, you'll get no benefits from haste until - at a minimum - you've added enough to fit another GCD into the 15s window. So...sure, you'll see a staircase, although the steps will be fairly uneven. (First, because the GCD drops as you add haste, so the stairs become progressively closer together. And second because there isn't always a good use for an extra GCD; sometimes your only option would be a - possibly clipped - mind flay.)

Of course, it isn't obvious that VT must be cast every 15s...
#686SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Originally Posted by Lazare
If you assume that VT must be cast every 15s no matter what, then you've reduced your choices to a recurring "how can I do the most DPS in the next 15s of dead time?" In that case, you'll get no benefits from haste until - at a minimum - you've added enough to fit another GCD into the 15s window. So...sure, you'll see a staircase, although the steps will be fairly uneven. (First, because the GCD drops as you add haste, so the stairs become progressively closer together. And second because there isn't always a good use for an extra GCD; sometimes your only option would be a - possibly clipped - mind flay.)

Of course, it isn't obvious that VT must be cast every 15s...
Well you can also cast VT every 16 or even 16.5 seconds if it works better that way. Generally the worst that happens is you miss a Pain tick, and even that doesn't happen always (since pain ticks once every three seconds).

On a related note, I've started clipping a few mind flays at 2 seconds if a high priority cooldown (touch or blast) is up. It's actually not as hard to do well as you'd think. I just watch the quartz timer until the seconds remaining reads 0.X and then cast immediately. Between lag and reasonable reflexes, I don't think I've missed the second tick yet, although I have hit it as late as 2.4 seconds. However, it seems like starting the mind blast cooldown a full second earlier is a huge win.

The other thing I've noticed while micromanaging my cycle is how often you have roughly between .5 and 1.5 seconds left on Mind Blast and nothing to do but Mind Flay. That simulator graph showed me how bad it was to cast a full mind flay when you only have .5 seconds left until blast, so I've started just adding deadtime in there, since it seems to be a net win. With 1.5 seconds, I often cast Mind Flay for 2 seconds and then Mind Blast. I'm not sure how this is affecting my damage, but it's definitely not dropping. It's probably just a minor improvement.

At any rate, I could easily see how another 100 points of haste would smooth out the cycle instead of adding more. Or maybe it will break even, smoothing out some issues but removing others. I'm not convinced that it's incorrect to use a flat, linear estimate for the value of a point of haste. Or at least for every 25 points of haste.
#687SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Goatharder

As for haste and VT, seems like a very viable point IF VT is actually that important that you can't lose any of it, as if you could you'd get to the point where you're supposed to VT but don't want to clip it and thus use a different spell first and then VT - which may or may not be a dps loss and will affect the benefit of haste (if any). While "forcing" VT every 15 seconds regardless is probably the right thing, I wouldn't jump to assume it without going over the numbers first and checking if delaying VT by a little is worth some flay gain (or better, earlier MB/SWD if they just came up). Not that simple to figure out but if the end result is that you should always refresh VT when it runs out even if that means waiting then haste becomes useless, at least in small amounts.
My guild is at the point right now where I'm starting to get outpaced by other DPS classes that have been gearing up (rogues/hunters/destro lock/arcane mage in particular), and I don't entirely mind it because as soon as we kill Kael, that gap is going to increase even more. I guess it all just comes down to a philosophy decision if you want to delay VT a bit to eke out a bit more DPS or if you want to get as close to a 5% return on damage as you can. I know I'm not going to be competitive with the rogues, and I'm not providing the second best reason to bring a spriest to raids by ignoring VT.

Then again, if the extent of the haste changes are drastic enough to get anywhere close, I'd love to abandon the above to get into e-peen fights with the rogues again. I just don't forsee that happening anytime soon, so I'll prolly sit down and work out the step function and pick up enough to jump up a 'tier' or two of extra DPS.
#688SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
tedv: Although I can't provide a graphic right now, since full simulator runs take significant time (that graphic was about 6 hours of computer time to produce), the results from the waiting variants of the sim more than confirm your theory on simply waiting for the MB cooldown being the right move. When I implement 2s clipped flays, I expect the window where waiting is beneficial to drop, but it certainly seems to be borne out that waiting for cooldowns improves DPS.

#691SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Ownageism
So with 2.4 releasing new gems that are spell haste, and with the GCD change, do you think it would be better to switch over to those gems? Maybe not the +8 spell haste gem, but the +4 spell haste +5 dmg gem?
#692SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â€¢ Snowy
Originally Posted by Ownageism
So with 2.4 releasing new gems that are spell haste, and with the GCD change, do you think it would be better to switch over to those gems? Maybe not the +8 spell haste gem, but the +4 spell haste +5 dmg gem?
Until I see more evidence I've just been ballparking spell haste to damage at a 1:1 ratio, so that would be the equivalent of a Runed Living Ruby. Basically it opens up options for getting socket bonuses -- and it remains to be seen what the new meta gem will take. You won't be able to use these gems if you're still using a MSD for example. It does make [Swift Starfire Diamond] a much easier meta to use though.
#693SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Arrian
Originally Posted by Ownageism
So with 2.4 releasing new gems that are spell haste, and with the GCD change, do you think it would be better to switch over to those gems? Maybe not the +8 spell haste gem, but the +4 spell haste +5 dmg gem?
The most generous estimates are that 1 haste = 1 or 1.1 spelldamage, so if you believe the latter the haste/damage gem would be 0.4 better than a living ruby. Personally, I'd say it would take some research and would only replace Living Rubies if the added haste got you to a point of inflection for DPS. Something like getting enough haste to fit 2 MF's between two 5/5 imp MBs. *edit* It's been so long that I've been looking at plain red that I didn't even think of the value of using them for socket bonuses. >.> */edit*

I think theorycrafting is seriously overvaluing the effect of a hasted GCD in practice. There a two methodological flaws I see in the models so far and the conclusions we draw from them.

First and perhapse minor is that most of the calculations for the value of haste I've seen are using higher spelldamage than is available with any significant amounts of haste. For example, the "Best ear Available" thread in shadowpriest.com values haste as calculated at 1400 spelldamage when ranking gear. I doubt even a majority of posters here will be able to have that level of spelldamage when converting to haste gear, let alone someone only in T5 content where they are trading significant spelldamage for haste.

Secondly, and more importantly, the damage gains are modeled as gains from increased Mind Flay damage and they're continuous functions. That is, they assume you will gain 5% more damage from Mind Flay if your haste rating allows you to cast Mind Flay 5% longer. Instead our damage is a discrete function where Mind Flay does 1/3 of its damage every 1/3 of its casting time. In practice this means you'll gain a tick of mind flay here and two ticks there. Lowering the global cooldown 10% doesn't mean you'll have an extra 6 seconds with nothing to do but flay after 54 seconds, those six seconds are mixed in between 15 and 24/27 second dot durations and 5.5 and 12 second nuke cooldowns and the gains are not guranteed to show up neatly in third increments of your Mind Flay casting time.

Finally, though not a systemic problem with the theories, the problem in practice is that you're assumed to have infinite, or at least sub tenth of a second precision with your casting. If your Mind Flay lasts 2.75 seconds, it's assumed that you will be able to interrupt it exactly 1.83 seconds to cast a 1.4 second Mind Blast. If you end up interrupting it at 1.9 seconds you just lost all the benefit from that hasted Mind Blast, and if you interrupt it at 1.80 seconds you just lost all the value of 4 1.4 second global cooldowns, roughlt 1/7th of the benefit you would get in one minute of casting. And that doesn't even begin to account for overlapping cooldowns.

That last point is the main reason I'm not particularly excited about these changes. In order to get the full value of haste we have to be exceptionally precise in our casting. Go over some WWSs and just look at your dot uptime. It's a pretty simple task to reapply a dot exactly when the previous dot dropped but you're doing very well if you can keep your uptime over 90% on any fight where you do more than just stand and cast for a couple minutes. If you're only 90% accurate on something that lasts a quarter or half a minute, how accurate can you be with something that lasts less than a second?

One more thing since I already have a wall of text up. The value of haste increased a lot compared to what it used to be but that doesn't mean it increased a whole lot in absolute terms. Haste used to be theorycrafted at about 1/2 of a point of spelldamage, it's doubled to being roughly as valuable as spelldamage, but your overall DPS gains aren't going to be tremendous since the final values are still within a hundred or so points of each other at the top end. Shadowpriest.com's haste thread has a post 3/4 of the way down that page saying the previous best gear available does 1333 dps on a spreadsheed where the new best gear with 240 more haste does 1370 dps with consumables.
#694SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Lazare
Arrian: Some good points, but two quick comments...

Originally Posted by Arrian
That last point is the main reason I'm not particularly excited about these changes. In order to get the full value of haste we have to be exceptionally precise in our casting. Go over some WWSs and just look at your dot uptime. It's a pretty simple task to reapply a dot exactly when the previous dot dropped but you're doing very well if you can keep your uptime over 90% on any fight where you do more than just stand and cast for a couple minutes. If you're only 90% accurate on something that lasts a quarter or half a minute, how accurate can you be with something that lasts less than a second?
True, but... Once you count lag and movement in, cast rotations are already pretty messy, and to max your DPS without any haste will require some split second timing. I'm not sure I agree that adding a realistic amount of spell haste really makes the problem worse.

Haste used to be theorycrafted at about 1/2 of a point of spelldamage, it's doubled to being roughly as valuable as spelldamage, but your overall DPS gains aren't going to be tremendous since the final values are still within a hundred or so points of each other at the top end. Shadowpriest.com's haste thread has a post 3/4 of the way down that page saying the previous best gear available does 1333 dps on a spreadsheed where the new best gear with 240 more haste does 1370 dps with consumables.
True, but simply adding some viable side grades is very helpful. I'm sure we've all been frustrated by waiting for a particular item that just wouldn't drop...

#696SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Arrian
Originally Posted by Balkoth
It does when you're sacrificing spell damage to get that haste. Which is the issue.
My sentiments exactly. I think I'll stick with the "If it's an upgrade without the haste, it's an upgrade with the haste" motto for comparing gear. Counting haste as being equal to x spell damage is oversimplifying things. I am excited about the GCD change with regards to Bloodlust, though. I don't spam my buttons since I used /stopcasting for so long and you can't spam those when there is possible pushback, I just cast and move on and sometimes miss the "This ability is not ready yet" message so I don't catch the missed cast until the next time I check my cooldowns which could be 5 or more seconds later.

#700SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Tymir
Well comparing Timbal's Focusing Crystal versus Hex Shrunken Head:
Timbal's Focusing Crystal- 44 static spell damage and a proc
Hex Shrunken Head- 88 spell damage if kept on cooldown

Therefore the proc from Timbal's Focusing Crystal must provide equivalent dps to 44 spell damage to break even.
At current itemization levels 1 spell damage = 0.5 dps, with the high amounts of haste on Sunwell gear 1 spell damage will equal slightly over 0.7 dps.

The average damage dealt by the Timbal's Focusing Crystal proc is 380 assuming it doesn't benefit from CoS or ISB and cant crit or be resisted.

380/60sec = 6.33 dps per proc/minute

Without haste:
(44 spell damage)*(.5 dps gain per spell damage) = 22 dps
(22 dps)/(6.33 dps per proc/minute) = 3.47 PPM required to break even with Hex Shrunken head

With Sunwell amounts of haste:
(44 spell damage)*(.7 dps gain per spell damage) = 30.8 dps
(30.8 dps)/(6.33 dps per proc/minute) = 4.86 PPM required to break even with Hex Shrunken head

If it does indeed have a 10% proc rate you are looking at a max of 4 ppm with 100% VT and SWP uptime. It should be a very good trinket even if it does not benefit from ISB charges, Misery, Shadow Weaving, or Curse of Shadows.
#701SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
I think people are entirely too locked into the idea that you absolutely must cast VT every 15 seconds. The reason my simulator isn't producing points of inflection is because it's willing to sacrifice a certain amount of VT time (the exact amount dependent on the wait function) - once you get off the idea you need to be locked exactly to 15 seconds, you'll note that the points of inflection are significantly mitigated, because you *can* get off that extra flay or blast or death.

People calculating haste:damage solely by trying to estimate MF percentages are certainly not going to come up accurate, but the 0.5:1 number is almost definitely inaccurate - it doesn't match my sims, and it doesn't seem to match people's real world experience either.

Final point re sims: I'm sitting at 1234 +shadow unbuffed, around 110 haste, without a HSH. +1400 shadow for haste sims is *not* unreasonable, since I'll be getting 80 from flask, 42 from oil, 23 from food, and a unspecified amount from my second trinket slot (I use Ashtongue or Blessings, depending on the fight).

As to Timbal's - I'll be shocked if it isn't affected by CoS/Misery/Weaving/ISB. The real question is whether any of our talents will affect it - odds are it will resist either way. Either way, it should be a solid trinket; might not beat out HSH, but may well be the second choice and beat out Icon.
#702SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv

As to Timbal's - I'll be shocked if it isn't affected by CoS/Misery/Weaving/ISB. The real question is whether any of our talents will affect it - odds are it will resist either way. Either way, it should be a solid trinket; might not beat out HSH, but may well be the second choice and beat out Icon.
I suspect it will work just like shadow damage from wands-- any debuffs on the target will affect the damage but no talents from the caster. So we're looking 113% * 105% * 110% * 120% = 156.6% of base damage best case. Or if your guild's Affliction Warlocks are like mine and think Improved Howl is good for raiding and Malediction is bad, you get around 151.5% of base damage. That's still really good. Even with 70% ISB uptime, you're looking at 145% damage.

#706SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â€¢ Snowy
Originally Posted by Kalman
I think people are entirely too locked into the idea that you absolutely must cast VT every 15 seconds. The reason my simulator isn't producing points of inflection is because it's willing to sacrifice a certain amount of VT time (the exact amount dependent on the wait function) - once you get off the idea you need to be locked exactly to 15 seconds, you'll note that the points of inflection are significantly mitigated, because you *can* get off that extra flay or blast or death.
Getting off that extra flay or blast or death is a boost to your own personal DPS, but keep in mind then you've boosted that damage at the expense of returning mana to your party, the primary reason why you're there. To me, refreshing VT every 15 seconds is paramount, everything past that is negotiable.
#707SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Cerine
Except, you generally start recasting 1.5 seconds before VT runs out. In that time, you can also finish up your MF or MB, and you'll generally be able to get VT up without losing anything except perhaps a single SW:P tick.
#708SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
Originally Posted by Snowy
Getting off that extra flay or blast or death is a boost to your own personal DPS, but keep in mind then you've boosted that damage at the expense of returning mana to your party, the primary reason why you're there. To me, refreshing VT every 15 seconds is paramount, everything past that is negotiable.
I used to think that way, but more and more it's become clear that it's more the presence of a shadow priest than the uptime/output. Is 225 mp5 vs. 200mp5 going to break your group? Almost never, especially not when you've gotten something down to the point where you're genuinely trying to max out dps.

That minor drop in MP5 from the occasional late refresh on VT is just not that big a deal when compared to your presence.

#710SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Originally Posted by Snowy

If they get 320 m/5 instead of 340 m/5, it doesn't matter because they still have enough mana. Last three fights in Black Temple are a different story though. After phase 2 though, the mana issues go away with one shadow fiend.

#711SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â€¢ DeeNogger
I am going to have to echo the feeling of others that pushing your own dps by a meaningful amount at the sacrifice of insignificant amounts of mana return is typically ok. Obviously there are situations when your group needs *every* last drop of mana you can give them, and there are also situations when anything above a marginal amount of VT return is more than enough. Most situations certainly fall in the gray area between the two, and it will take a marginal amount of intelligence on the SP to decide when it is safe to allow your VT efficiency to slip to pursue better dps and when it is not. Not unlike knowing when to SW:Death and when not to.

As far as farming T6, which is hardly as important as the future progression raids of Sunwell, VT return efficiency can seriously dip without any consequence on most, but not all, fights. The exceptions would be Council, Illidan, Kazgalor, and Shahraz. Typical dps slug fests (Terron) certainly do *not* require maximum VT efficiency simply because they are over and done with far too quickly. However, Sunwell encounters could completely turn all this on its head, as a fight can highly dictate how important mana is (duh) just as a fight's specific mechanics can determine weather SW:D is safe or not (at least when learning it).

#715SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Zigs
I think it comes down to what youâ€™re going to miss the mana return from. I agree that letting one SW: P tick slip through isn't that bad but if you hold off casting the VT to sneak a MB in and the VT is down by the time the MB hits it could have a noticeable effect in aggregate.

This discussion is getting off point though. The main idea is how much haste is going to contribute to our DPS. Shadowpriest.com has a thread up with gear a ranking which is assuming a 1:1 haste to damage ratio. From the discussion here I think that ratio is far too high. At most a certain value of haste will allow you to sneak in another GCD in the ~15sec window between VTs. Therefore there should be a sweetspot at which point stacking more haste does nothing for you since you will never be able to sneak in two global cooldowns. That's what people are talking about when they speak of points of inflection.

The question on the table is what is the magic number for haste? Then it becomes how to achieve that number with the highest raw damage while remaining hit capped.
#716SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Originally Posted by Zigs
This discussion is getting off point though. The main idea is how much haste is going to contribute to our DPS. Shadowpriest.com has a thread up with gear a ranking which is assuming a 1:1 haste to damage ratio. From the discussion here I think that ratio is far too high. At most a certain value of haste will allow you to sneak in another GCD in the ~15sec window between VTs. Therefore there should be a sweetspot at which point stacking more haste does nothing for you since you will never be able to sneak in two global cooldowns. That's what people are talking about when they speak of points of inflection.

The question on the table is what is the magic number for haste? Then it becomes how to achieve that number with the highest raw damage while remaining hit capped.
If your goal is gaining another 1.5 / (1 + haste) seconds every 15 seconds then:

Normal cast time: 15
Hasted cast time: 15 / (1 + haste)
15 - 15 / (1 + haste) = 1.5 / (1 + haste)

Now just solve for the haste percent:

15 = 16.5 / (1 + haste)
15 + 15 * haste = 16.5
haste = 1.5 / 15 = 10%

So you'll need 157 haste rating to get 10% haste. I'm not convinced of the magic number theory, but if there is one, the first step would be at 157 and the second at 20% haste (314). I highly doubt the spell damage loss is worth stacking 314 haste though.
#717SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Zigs
Originally Posted by tedv
I highly doubt the spell damage loss is worth stacking 314 haste though.

There isn't a spell damage loss at 314. Here's what I'm looking at:



Edit: Note, the hit on the helm is from the enchant so it is the same for nonengineers. Also, the listed helm +damge is including a pre nerf MSD so it will be much lower.

The real question is how much spell damage you could get if you focused on the damage oriented pieces from black temple-- how much would you give up to get the haste listed in your example?

#720SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Woozle
Another concern of mine with regard to damage v. haste is the lack of +hit on sunwell items. Assuming a standard spec of full imp. mind blast, you get 3 points for shadow focus, meaning (obviously) your gear needs to cover the other 10%. The list above only has 84 hit, which comes in at (rough guess) just under 7%. Are people considering dropping talents to cover the missing hit? Or is it more practical to substitute more items with hit in less critical areas to keep damage and haste maxed (I'm thinking along the lines of the Wand of Prismatic Focus). The latter seems like the clearly better option, especially considering 4 pc. T6 is going to be much easier to maintain, but it might mean a little more balancing in terms of gear selection.
#721SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Zigs

Assuming a standard spec of full imp. mind blast, you get 3 points for shadow focus, meaning (obviously) your gear needs to cover the other 10%. The list above only has 84 hit, which comes in at (rough guess) just under 7%. Are people considering dropping talents to cover the missing hit? Or is it more practical to substitute more items with hit in less critical areas to keep damage and haste maxed (I'm thinking along the lines of the Wand of Prismatic Focus). The latter seems like the clearly better option, especially considering 4 pc. T6 is going to be much easier to maintain, but it might mean a little more balancing in terms of gear selection.
You have to drop imp VE and most likely a point out of meditation. You need 78 hit to cap. If you don't have the skull you can sub it out for the new BoE JC ring and be at 78 exactly.
#722SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
New MSD is ~2/3 as good as old MSD, for the record. If they boost it to the 6 second tooltip duration, it'll be roughly equivalent.

#725SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â€¢ Althor
Originally Posted by tedv
I suspect it will work just like shadow damage from wands-- any debuffs on the target will affect the damage but no talents from the caster. So we're looking 113% * 105% * 110% * 120% = 156.6% of base damage best case. Or if your guild's Affliction Warlocks are like mine and think Improved Howl is good for raiding and Malediction is bad, you get around 151.5% of base damage. That's still really good. Even with 70% ISB uptime, you're looking at 145% damage.
Shadowform affects Shadow wands.

#729SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Unless you are undead and need to cast Devouring Plague, I'd cut Inner Focus over the third point in meditation. Saving 350 mana every 3 minutes on a Mind Blast is roughly 10 m/5, which seems a lot less than each point of meditation. I guess you lose 25% of 50% of 2400 damage once every 3 minutes from reduced crit chance, but that's just a 1.6 DPS loss.
#730SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Cerine
Well, technically, if you use it on SW:P (575 mana), IF is worth 16mp5. Also, if you chain it to a MF and follow it with a MB, you'll get a tick of OO5sr regen.
#731SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Originally Posted by Cerine
Well, technically, if you use it on SW:P (575 mana), IF is worth 16mp5. Also, if you chain it to a MF and follow it with a MB, you'll get a tick of OO5sr regen.
You only get the out of combat mana tick if you cast an instant spell, then inner focus the mind flay, and then cast a 1.5 second spell. Here's the cast sequence without inner focus:

0: Random Previous Mindflay (Mana cost paid up front = Low regen start, leave at 5.0)
3.0: Shadow Word Pain (Mana cost paid = Low regen start, leave at 8.0)
4.5: GCD up, cast Mind Flay. (Low Regen start again, leave at 9.5)
7.5: Mind Flay complete, Mind Blast start
9.0: Mind Blast cast (Low regen start again, leave at 14.0)

As you can see, putting Inner Focus on the Shadow Word Pain does nothing for out of cast time regen, since as soon as you cast the Mind Flay after it, you enter the 5 second rule again. Remember, Mind Flay is an instant cast DoT that requires channeling to maintain the DoT! It is NOT the same as a 3 second cast Fireball. Because the mana for mind flay is deducted at the start, that's when you enter the low regen state.

Now if you Inner Focus your Mind Flay at 4.5 seconds, you will leave low regen at 8.0 and enter at 9.0, giving you half a tick. Plus you wasted inner focus on a 185 mana spell rather than a 550 mana spell, and I doubt you gained an extra 365 mana in that second.

At any rate, the value of Meditation scales up with you gear while Inner Focus does not, so to me that says Inner Focus is the talent to cut. Unless of course you were lucky enough to spec Devouring Plague.
#732SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Ownageism
So a shadow priest friend of mine got onto the PTR yesterday (I still can't get on), and he managed to snag the Timbal's trinket. These are the results that he came up with:

It is indeed a 10% proc.
He said it appears to have an internal CD of 15sec. He never had a proc sooner than 18sec.
It CAN crit (he's not sure if it has a set % to crit or not).
Not only can it proc from our DoTs, but he also got it to proc from Mind Flay, which means it can be procced via channeled spells.
Will work with Shadow Weaving talent and Curse of Shadows.

A look over at Wowhead shows a warlock having identical results as well, with a tad more information (his soonest proc was after 17sec).

The questions left for me are:

Do they consume ISB charges?
Is it based on our personal crit% or does it have a set % to crit?

Other than that, this trinket seems even more badass than before. Your all's thoughts?
#733SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Originally Posted by tedv
Remember, Mind Flay is an instant cast DoT that requires channeling to maintain the DoT!
Originally Posted by Ownageism
So a shadow priest friend of mine got onto the PTR yesterday (I still can't get on), and he managed to snag the Timbal's trinket. These are the results that he came up with:

It is indeed a 10% proc.
He said it appears to have an internal CD of 15sec. He never had a proc sooner than 18sec.
It CAN crit (he's not sure if it has a set % to crit or not).
Not only can it proc from our DoTs, but he also got it to proc from Mind Flay, which means it can be procced via channeled spells.
It doesn't proc from Arcane Missiles, which is a channel spell that casts a bolt every second. Also remember that Mind Flay ticks do not crit while Arcane Missiles can. As a rule of thumb, if it crits, it's direct damage. Otherwise it's periodic damage (a DoT). We should probably add something like this to the root post because people often get confused about this point.

Since that the spell from Tymbal's can crit, I'm 99% certain it will consume ISB charges and that it uses your spell crit, not the default 5%.

We average one DoT tick per second in a full burn cycle with no haste, which means we average 1 proc every 25 seconds. Interestingly enough, this gets slightly stronger if you're doing a mana intense fight or if you're dotting multiple targets, since you'll average one proc per 20 seconds. But I can't think of any examples of the former, and for the latter you'd rather just get 80% uptime on your ashtonge trinket.
#734SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Evanwill
I thought I'd share a post I made on SP.com of some work I've done with the Shadow Priest DPS spreadsheet. It should give people a good idea of what haste will do for you dps at different levels of damage and haste.

Here's some quick "simulations" I did with the DPS spreadsheet that I modified a bit. It's linked here. All I did was change the damage and haste values in the spreadsheet and recorded the DPS values it produced. As you can see from the graphs, there are definitely some "plateaus" at certain haste values that seem to coincide regardless of how damage you have. The right way to do this would be to model it for each point of haste at each point of damage, but I don't have the time for that . These are in done in 100 damage intervals (1000-1500) with increments of 25 haste (0-500).

Sample screen of my settings while generating the data. This was the 1500 damage/500 haste calculation.


Values the graphs are created from. If people want to run the simulations more rigorously, you can decrease the increments of haste and damage.


Graphs.
Last edited by Evanwill : 02/13/08 at 5:09 PM.
#735SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3UnholY_Prince
Hey Evan, great work with the modeling, should be a really useful tool for the SP community to refer to.

Quick question, were these models run at 0 latency?
#736SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Evanwill
Lag was set to .15s. Everything in the first screenshot remained constant except for the haste and damage values.
#737SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3nataku
Originally Posted by tedv
It doesn't proc from Arcane Missiles, which is a channel spell that casts a bolt every second. Also remember that Mind Flay ticks do not crit while Arcane Missiles can. As a rule of thumb, if it crits, it's direct damage. Otherwise it's periodic damage (a DoT). We should probably add something like this to the root post because people often get confused about this point.

Since that the spell from Tymbal's can crit, I'm 99% certain it will consume ISB charges and that it uses your spell crit, not the default 5%.

We average one DoT tick per second in a full burn cycle with no haste, which means we average 1 proc every 25 seconds. Interestingly enough, this gets slightly stronger if you're doing a mana intense fight or if you're dotting multiple targets, since you'll average one proc per 20 seconds. But I can't think of any examples of the former, and for the latter you'd rather just get 80% uptime on your ashtonge trinket.
With more spell haste, you should end up with more mind flay ticks as well, which should increase the value of the proc. Currently, with moderate spell haste (staff, 2x rings, bracers), mind flay has already started becoming 28-31% of my damage for a typical wws parse on many fights, which bumps me up to 1.1-1.2 ticks per second.

The consumption of ISB charges is a concern though since we rely on it so much for bumping up our DoT/Flay damage. Hopefully a lock can check on that.

I'm paper napkin calculating ~25-30 dps from the trinket proc based on my 1.15 dot ticks per second, but may result in a much steeper penalty of lower ISB uptime, especially with multiple trinket users.
#738SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Do you mind running these simulations at the 1600, 1700, and 1800 ranges? I know I average over 1500 when raid buffed, and 1800 is reasonable with a shaman and trinkets up.

Looking over the graphs, the plateaus seem to be near 157 and 314 haste rating (nudged a bit due to lag). These correspond to the haste needed to squeeze in one and two extra GCDs. The graph is still pretty linear (perhaps due to the coarse granularity). Looking at the 300 haste DPS increase over 0 DPS, it looks like you'll need 1550 spell damage to get 1 haste = 1 spell damage. I think this means haste is not a stat we should explicitly stack. Rather it's something to balance along with spell damage.

Originally Posted by nataku
With more spell haste, you should end up with more mind flay ticks as well, which should increase the value of the proc. Currently, with moderate spell haste (staff, 2x rings, bracers), mind flay has already started becoming 28-31% of my damage for a typical wws parse on many fights, which bumps me up to 1.1-1.2 ticks per second.
Even if you could get 2 ticks a second (only possible with chain mind flay, both dots up, and a ton of haste), it's the 15 second internal cooldown that limits the proc rate. You'll average one proc every 20 seconds if you somehow got 2 ticks a seconds. That's 25% more damage than one proc every 25 second, which is good but probably not good enough.
#739SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Evanwill

The graph is still pretty linear (perhaps due to the coarse granularity). Looking at the 300 haste DPS increase over 0 DPS, it looks like you'll need 1550 spell damage to get 1 haste = 1 spell damage. I think this means haste is not a stat we should explicitly stack. Rather it's something to balance along with spell damage.
I uploaded my modified spreadsheet if you don't want to wait for me to do it (it might be a day or so). It does take some time because you have to go through and enter each haste value for each damage value. If I was better with Excel, I'd design it to plot a graph for every point of haste from 0-788 for whatever damage value you enter (Anyone now how to do this??).

Last edited by Evanwill : 02/13/08 at 5:25 PM.
#740SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		tetracycloide
I have written a macro that takes the existing version of the spread sheet and adds an additional sheet and then fills in all the values you would need to create a graph out of your own inputs. It only goes from 1-500 haste rating at the moment but that could be set higher very easily. This is a work in progress that I'm still tweaking but it does automate the process at least so you do not physically have to sit there and do it. Error handling could use some work.

From the excel menu go to tools select macro then go to visual basic editor.
From the visual basic editor find the "Project -VBAProject" window (should be top left).
In that window find the line VBAProject(priest_dps.xls) and right click on this line.
Select insert from the menu that pops up and then module from the subsequent menu.
Paste the following into the large window on the right:

Sub CreateHasteSheet()
    Sheets("Spell Data").Select
    Sheets.Add
    Sheets("Sheet1").Select
    Sheets("Sheet1").Move After:=Sheets(5)
    Sheets("Sheet1").Select
    Sheets("Sheet1").Name = "HasteGraph"
    Range("A1").Select
    ActiveCell.FormulaR1C1 = "Haste"
    Range("B1").Select
    ActiveCell.FormulaR1C1 = "DPS"
Call dps(1)

End Sub
Sub CreateHasteSheetAgain()
Call dps(1)
End Sub



Sub dps(hasterating)
If hasterating <= 500 Then
    Sheets("Shadow DPS Information").Select
    Range("H32").Select
    ActiveCell.FormulaR1C1 = hasterating
    Range("I12").Select
    Selection.Copy
    Sheets("HasteGraph").Select
    Range("A" & hasterating + 1).Select
    ActiveCell.FormulaR1C1 = hasterating
    Range("B" & hasterating + 1).Select
    Selection.PasteSpecial Paste:=xlPasteValues, Operation:=xlNone, SkipBlanks _
        :=False, Transpose:=False
    hasterating = hasterating + 1
Call dps(hasterating)
Else
End If
End Sub

Once that is done switch back to the excel window. Go to the tools menu back to macro and now hit the Macros option with the little green triangle next to it. From the macro window that pops up select 'CreateHasteSheet' the first time and 'CreateHasteSheetAgain' for each subsequent run. Running 'CreateHasteSheet' more than once will result in an error. On reruns the old values will be overwritten. Both functions are time consuming.
Last edited by tetracycloide : 02/13/08 at 6:03 PM. Reason: clarity
#741SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tetracycloide
I've run the macro above a few times at different shadow damage levels while keeping all of the other variables constant and there seem to be four very consistant points where adding haste actually reduces overall DPS:

20
209
279
445

At these points the graph will dip dramatically and then start rising again at roughly the same slope as before the dip eventually passing the old local maxima at the above values and continuing upward.
#742SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Evanwill
Tetracycloide, thank you for the help. By using your code as an example and mashing the F1 button, I've got something put together that is fairly user friendly. It's still pretty slow so if you want to do a full sim from 0 to 788 haste at a desired spell damage value, it will take several minutes. At least you don't have to type them all in!

Here's the link priest_dps_graph.xls - FileFront.com

#744SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Firekrotc
Originally Posted by tetracycloide
I've run the macro above a few times at different shadow damage levels while keeping all of the other variables constant and there seem to be four very consistant points where adding haste actually reduces overall DPS:

20
209
279
445

At these points the graph will dip dramatically and then start rising again at roughly the same slope as before the dip eventually passing the old local maxima at the above values and continuing upward.
Haste should never reduce dps. No matter how much haste you have, the option of casting each spell exactly at the same time you would have done with 0 haste is always there.

This leads me to suspect that there is a logic issue with the spell casting in the spreadsheet. Without looking into it I can't be sure, but my guess would be that it is choosing to cast flays instead of waiting a small time for a cd to be up.
