#751SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Asmo
Originally Posted by Firekrotc
Haste should never reduce dps. No matter how much haste you have, the option of casting each spell exactly at the same time you would have done with 0 haste is always there.

This leads me to suspect that there is a logic issue with the spell casting in the spreadsheet. Without looking into it I can't be sure, but my guess would be that it is choosing to cast flays instead of waiting a small time for a cd to be up.
Yes that is exactly it, I've played around with different spell haste values myself in the spreadsheet and it does at certain points reduce your dps unless you tweak the "wait" value for each spellhaste number. If I did that I always got an increase. So for it to be accurate you would need a macro or something that also finds the wait value (and possibly also mindflay interrupt value) for each haste number that results in the highest dps.
#752SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Metrosexuelf
Anyone run some numbers on the Shattered Sun exalted necklaces yet? Apparently, and these are largely unsubstantiated rumors based on data mining, the Aldor one yields a +100ish damage proc for 10 seconds while the Scryer one yields a +crit rating proc (yes there are those of us who picked Scryer without considering everything and/or if we were going to raid). Obviously the former is appealing while the latter is horrible.

I'm curious as to how it would stack up against the Zul'Aman neck or even the new PvP neck, [Vindicator's Pendant of Subjugation], given the haste changes.
#753SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tetracycloide
Originally Posted by Asmo
Yes that is exactly it, I've played around with different spell haste values myself in the spreadsheet and it does at certain points reduce your dps unless you tweak the "wait" value for each spellhaste number. If I did that I always got an increase. So for it to be accurate you would need a macro or something that also finds the wait value (and possibly also mindflay interrupt value) for each haste number that results in the highest dps.
I agree that without tweaking the 'wait' values the complete picture of the gains from haste will not be realized but because of the nature of the graphs that are being produced by fully stepping out haste from 1-x in single point incriments the tweaking need not be done to attach a meaningful weight to haste as a stat.

All of the graphs that I have produced with the macro so far have all demonstrated the exact same behaviour which is, namely, a step wise linear function. Adjusting the wait values in the sheet would ultimately produce a completely linear graph or at least an aproximation of one given the amount of variance in the sim itself. That is to say the slope of the line is what matters, not the nominal DPS number that is being produced by the sim.

That said adding in logic to the macro that creates the values to adjust the wait times for maximum DPS is completely possible but as long as it is just guessing and checking it would make the function more time consuming.
#754SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		â—Š Kalman
Originally Posted by tetracycloide
I agree that without tweaking the 'wait' values the complete picture of the gains from haste will not be realized but because of the nature of the graphs that are being produced by fully stepping out haste from 1-x in single point incriments the tweaking need not be done to attach a meaningful weight to haste as a stat.
Wrong. Tweaking wait is *absolutely* required to produce meaningful estimates of haste's value as a stat. A 0.1 second variance in wait can produce a variance of +/-2-3% in DPS, which is quite significant.
Last edited by Kalman : 02/18/08 at 12:38 PM. Reason: clarification
#755SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tetracycloide
Originally Posted by Kalman
Wrong. Tweaking wait is *absolutely* required to produce meaningful estimates of haste's value as a stat. A 0.1 second variance in wait can produce a variance of 2-3% in DPS, which is quite significant.
The weight of the stat is a function of its relative effect on DPS. You don't need to tweak the wait stat in order to determine that value because the graph is stepwise linear. All stepping out the wait values is going to do is smooth out the graph so it is completely linear instead of piecewise linear. The distinction between the two is completely academic because the slope is the weight of the stat and for the linear pieces of either graph it will be the same.

It does depend on what you're using the sheet for though. I should amend my argument by saying I would only be interested in using the sheet to assign approximate stat weights that can be used to select gear. If you are actually trying to created a DPS number to match with in game then, yes, the estimate of your DPS will require tweaking of the wait stat to remain accurate.
#756SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
Originally Posted by tetracycloide
The weight of the stat is a function of its relative effect on DPS. You don't need to tweak the wait stat in order to determine that value because the graph is stepwise linear. All stepping out the wait values is going to do is smooth out the graph so it is completely linear instead of piecewise linear. The distinction between the two is completely academic because the slope is the weight of the stat and for the linear pieces of either graph it will be the same.
Actually, changing the wait timing is going to convert it from piecewise linear non-monotonic to piecewise linear monotonic, which is a very important difference.
#757SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tetracycloide
Originally Posted by Kalman
Actually, changing the wait timing is going to convert it from piecewise linear non-monotonic to piecewise linear monotonic, which is a very important difference.
I think you're missing the point, I only care about the slope. The slope is the same whether you adjust the wait time or not, once you fully step out the data point to 1 haste rating or less. Unless you've already plotted a graph at that level of fidelity and observed something different in which case I'd be interested in seeing the data set. A change in the slope of the line because of changing the wait values would indicate that adjusting your spell casting will make the value of haste increase the more haste you have, which is contrary to what I've read in other threads and my own research.
#758SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
Originally Posted by tetracycloide
I think you're missing the point, I only care about the slope. The slope is the same whether you adjust the wait time or not, once you fully step out the data point to 1 haste rating or less. Unless you've already plotted a graph at that level of fidelity and observed something different in which case I'd be interested in seeing the data set. A change in the slope of the line because of changing the wait values would indicate that adjusting your spell casting will make the value of haste increase the more haste you have, which is contrary to what I've read in other threads and my own research.
The slope is not the same when you step the data out to 1 haste rating. I've done it. I've even provided code for other people to do it (sorry, not going to try to do simulation in Excel when I have MATLAB available). Haste rating's value is NOT LINEAR ACROSS THE RANGE. It is piecewise linear in small chunks, yes, but that implies slope variation. Adding wait timing simply changes the nature of the piecewise linearity - it doesn't suddenly make it linear across the range.

Adjusting your cast timing will, in fact, change the value of haste at a given point. Since the required value varies, and the graph itself remains piecewise linear whether you adjust or not, the slope change is meaningful given wait time variation.
#759SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tetracycloide
Originally Posted by Kalman
The slope is not the same when you step the data out to 1 haste rating. I've done it. I've even provided code for other people to do it (sorry, not going to try to do simulation in Excel when I have MATLAB available). Haste rating's value is NOT LINEAR ACROSS THE RANGE. It is piecewise linear in small chunks, yes, but that implies slope variation. Adding wait timing simply changes the nature of the piecewise linearity - it doesn't suddenly make it linear across the range.

Adjusting your cast timing will, in fact, change the value of haste at a given point. Since the required value varies, and the graph itself remains piecewise linear whether you adjust or not, the slope change is meaningful given wait time variation.
Then your mathlab numbers are different than the simulation in the excel sheet because that is very much not the behaviour of the simulation in the spread sheet. In the excel sheet if the wait times are adjusted to optimal values given a specific haste rating and the DPS points at each value of haste are graph it does make it linear across the range. This makes sense because piecewise linear implies changing intercepts, not changing slopes.

What you are saying right now is that each marginal point of haste is worth a different amount, given a fixed set of other stats, depending on how much haste you have. The simulation in the sheet indicates that each marginal point of haste is worth the same amount, given a fixed set of other stats, reguardless of how much haste you have as long as you adjust your cast timing optimally.
#760SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
I think your math is a little bit wrong. Piecewise linear implies that the slope is constant across each piece, not across the range (defining range as from 0 to N haste, N generally being on the order of 250-300 since those are maximum practical haste ratings). In fact, piecewise linear more or less requires different slopes, even if on very short segments - if you have uniform slope across a line, that line is not piecewise, it's simple linear.

And yes, haste has differential value depending on how much of it you have. That's obvious from a moment's thought about it.

edit: At any rate, running a full battery across 0:250 haste at 0,0.1,...,0.9,1.0 wait vals, will post a graphic when it's complete.
#761SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tetracycloide
Originally Posted by Kalman
I think your math is a little bit wrong. Piecewise linear implies that the slope is constant across each piece, not across the range (defining range as from 0 to N haste, N generally being on the order of 250-300 since those are maximum practical haste ratings). In fact, piecewise linear more or less requires different slopes, even if on very short segments - if you have uniform slope across a line, that line is not piecewise, it's simple linear.

And yes, haste has differential value depending on how much of it you have. That's obvious from a moment's thought about it.

edit: At any rate, running a full battery across 0:250 haste at 0,0.1,...,0.9,1.0 wait vals, will post a graphic when it's complete.
A curve can be piecewise linear with a constant slope and a changing intercept. This is what I observed building a curve out of the data produced by varying the haste value and running the sim for DPS. Piecewise linear doesn't require different slopes because a piecewise linear equation where the disjointed segments that all have the same slopes but different intercepts will have a constant derivative across the entire range. The slope from 0 to 250-300 is a completely different value than the instantaneous slope at any given point.

Haste adding different amounts of DPS depending on how much you already is true on live, now that I've thought about it, because of the GCD lock. Assuming 2.4 goes live as is this will no longer be the case. My mistake. The sheet is built with the GCD lock built in so I maintain, based on the graphs that the sheet is producing for me with its simulation, that in the sheet changing the wait values still only changes the intercepts on the various pieces in the graph and not the instantaneous slope at any given point. Again, this is merely what I'm observing from the output of the sheet and if it's incorrect the sheet should be fixed.
#762SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
I'm not going to fix the sheet. Excel for programmatic simulation is just a bad tool.

Attached: simulation using 2.4 GCD, in increments of 1 haste, timestep of 0.01 seconds, 15 minute fights, across 250 haste at 10 different values of wait. While the shapes are, overall, *similar*, they are not identical. Essentially, as wait increases, peaks/troughs are flattened out.

Note that further smoothing of the graph can be seen as wait is boosted. However, waiting longer isn't always optimal - sometimes it does lower your DPS, while making the graph across haste closer to monotonically increasing. Hence my stipulation that wait is not something you can simply set and have be valid across the range of hastes.
Attached Thumbnails

#767SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
AD trinket is fine, for what it's worth. I'm not sure why people are so down on it - it isn't best in slot (or even close to), it's beaten out by Icon/Head/Skull, but is competitive with Blessings (before I got a head, I swapped between Blessings and AD Exalted depending on fight - if Blessings resets a couple times, or if you multidot, AD Exalted beats it). SotS ring isn't exactly bad either - it's a solid ring, certainly. Neither is worth going human for (especially not the trinket - AD rep comes FAST).

Re: racials - NE have highest personal damage, draenei have highest group benefit (higher mana return as well as a 1% spellhit aura). Dwarf shadow is inferior in all respects for PvE. Human shadow is okay - small damage boost and personal regen boost from human spirit, repgrind reduction, but inferior output in the two main categories to night elf and draenei (damage/regen).

#771SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Woozle
Ceran, at first glance it looks like that WWS is collected over several hours of raid time. That would explain why the DPS time is less than 100%, since it includes downtime between trash and bosses. Probably the easiest mob to track your DPS for in that WWS is going to be Rage Winterchill, even though its a short fight. You could also contrast that with Illidari Council, as thats a longer fight with a little more movement. If you can, try to get ahold of WWS for teron, as that seems to be the benchmark most people go off of when analyzing DPS cycles.

To analyze the WWS, use the "split" tab to focus on the fight you are interested in, and use the "browse" tab to highlight your contribution.

To see your Rage breakdown : Ceran - WWS
To see your Council breakdown: Ceran - WWS

With regard to dot clipping, there isn't any immediate way to read how often you are clipping your dots per se. The easiest way is to read the amount of time the fight took (look in the summary tab), and (I believe, might be wrong its late) divide by 3. Since both your dots tick every 3 seconds, the ideal fight (assuming no multi target dotting) would be (dps time)/3. The closer you are getting to that, the more confident you can be you aren't clipping your dots.
Last edited by Woozle : 02/23/08 at 2:07 AM.
#772SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tadrinth
Kalman, your graph is very interesting. It looks like there are 2 different curves. The higher curve is the result of proper wait times, and the lower one is the result of not waiting long enough. Which one do you think is closer to a real world approximation? I would expect human reactions adjusting wait times on the fly to be closer to the optimal curve. What spell damage did you assume for this simulation?

There also seem to be quite sharp diminishing returns on haste, with a plateau between 150 and 200 spell haste. That would put the sweet spot between 100 and 150.

Evanwill's numbers also show a plateau, but around 100-150. That's one of the places where small amounts of waiting make a big difference, though.

How much +damage does it take to add 1 dps? I'd like to try to calculate the relative usefulness of haste vs damage. I've seen reports of 0.5 haste = 1 damage for live, all the way up to 1 haste = 1 damage for PTR. It should be easy to calculate from the graphs if I can convert from DPS to +damage.
#773SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
The graph was run at 1400 +dmg. I suspect that human reaction will wind up somewhere in the top-middle of the bounds, as people don't tend to play perfectly; that said, the penalty for being 'close' tends to be fairly low (though not always).

I don't know if Evan is running under 2.4 GCD assumptions; I was. I expect that would make a difference in where the 'plateau' lands. Roughly speaking, 2 +dmg = 1 +dps; on PTR, the haste:damage conversion does appear to be close to 1:1 at the 250 range, Even at the 'plateau', it still appears to be on the order of 0.8:1. There's also some indication that the plateau may end and past 250 it may boost back up, I need to run some more simulations.

For 2.4, I basically expect +haste to be roughly 1:1 with +dmg, between the combination of it appearing very close to that value in simulations and the unsimulated benefits (motion fights have higher cast allowances.)
#774SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Anderung
Haste & Trinkets
I'm very pleased to have found this forum... finally, people that speak my language. Shadow Priest.

As a guild leader having to lead Kara runs with my newly-70's and my weekly-casuals (not very elitist... I know...), every week I've been picking up extra badges that, until news of the 2.4 badge rewards, were just burning holes in my bags. I started messing around with spell haste gear and I can confirm that you guys are right on the money with the +3 spell haste = +1 DPS that you've been kicking around in this thread -- Kudos to the math-crunching Shadows! I've found that depending on the piece of gear that I'm swapping out, it's more a matter of what am I losing to gain the haste :: and in many cases, I've come out ahead after the math-splosion (for example... the Runed Spell-cuffs vs Bands of Nefarious Deeds).

Additionally, I picked up the Essence of the Martyr for my healing set (*gasp* A healing set!? not very elitist at ALL... I know...), and I found out that the Essence is on a separate CD from the Icon of the Silver Crescent. So, am I right to assume the following:

In general...

Icon = (155/6) + 43 = +68.83 effective
Essence = (99/6) + 28 = +44.5 effective
TRINKET TOTAL = +113.33

... but for fights that last for 20secs or less (i.e. most trash fights)...

Icon = 155 + 43 = +198
Essence = 99 + 28 = +127
TRINKET TOTAL = +325

Since there is generally downtime between trash pulls (drinking, rezing, moving to the next pull, rebuffing, joking around on Vent, etc...), I've found that this trinket combo has dramatically increased my combat effective DPS, especially since I have both trinkets linked to every damage casting spell in my arsenal using macros (so the trinkets are being popped at every possible chance).

Thoughts?
#775SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tadrinth
After a round of number crunching this morning, I think the Runed Spell-cuffs will be my next badge purchase. They work out to 0.8 more +damage equivalents per badge over my current gear, which blows away everything else available per badge. Glad to hear that the real world results are satisfactory, Anderung!

On my warlock I used a mod called TwinTrinkets to rotate trinkets based on cooldown. I only macroed trinkets to DOT spells though, because it's sort of a waste to pop a trinket during the last 5s of a fight. Usually I would wind up with a trinket cooling in my bags, a trinket freshly equipped with the 30s cooldown, and a trinket ready to go for most trash pulls.

#778SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Elerion
Scryers/Aldor isn't likely to continue to be relevant in the new expansion. There's no way to go above exalted for existing characters, and it would create a need for new characters to farm "new old world" zones to catch up. It just doesn't mesh with Blizzard's expansion philosophy (the giant reset button).

I don't think it's that likely lorewise either. The Scryer/Aldor conflict arc has pretty much reached its happy friendly conclusion through BT and SW storylines.

So while the storyline may be utilized I'm sure the reputation will become meaningless. Well, once new shoulder enchants pop up, anyway.
#779SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3cheebamonkey
I've been toying around with doing Mathematica simulations and a very basic VT>SWP>MB>SWD>MF logic. I haven't yet incorporated latency in yet but here is what I've seen so far looking at haste for 2.4:



The simulations were ran for 10,000 seconds with time steps of .01 seconds at various haste multiples of 10 between 10 and 500. As you can see there is a drop off just after 140 haste (which will give you about 2.75 sec MF's) and then it's a fairly consistent increase after that. My guess is that this is because the dps cycle comes closest to an actual "cycle" at this value and then becomes more chaotic after that.

Since this takes a while to run I'm going to let it sit for a day and get a full spectrum from 1-500 sometime this week. I'm thinking of doing latency as .1+.1*RandomReal[] so it varies randomly between .1 and .2. Any thoughts on it?
#780SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Tabaggins
Originally Posted by cheebamonkey
I've been toying around with doing Mathematica simulations and a very basic VT>SWP>MB>SWD>MF logic. I haven't yet incorporated latency in yet but here is what I've seen so far looking at haste for 2.4:

The simulations were ran for 10,000 seconds with time steps of .01 seconds at various haste multiples of 10 between 10 and 500. As you can see there is a drop off just after 140 haste (which will give you about 2.75 sec MF's) and then it's a fairly consistent increase after that. My guess is that this is because the dps cycle comes closest to an actual "cycle" at this value and then becomes more chaotic after that.

Since this takes a while to run I'm going to let it sit for a day and get a full spectrum from 1-500 sometime this week. I'm thinking of doing latency as .1+.1*RandomReal[] so it varies randomly between .1 and .2. Any thoughts on it?
I am interested in the drop off after the 2.75s MF mark. In reality, this should be a plateau at worst when considering delaying spells. Perhaps implementing this into the logic for in the form: delay cast by (time left on CD) iff (damage of next spell in cycle ) / (time left on CD + cast time) > (damage of current spell in the cycle) / (cast time). This is something that could result in more practical data and may be worth the extra time if you are going to long simulation.

#783SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Morogoth
The other thing to look at when doing this simulation. I know a lot of shadow priests have begun to use partial mindflays, ie break the mindflay after 1 or 2 ticks when a higher damage spell becomes available. Having the simulator take this into account would be interesting to see.

From what I have read that decrease is due to the fact instead of waiting an extra 1 or 2 tenths of a second, the simulator does a whole mindflay instead of a mindblast or some other high dps spell. This then actually lowers our dps.
#784SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Tifi
Originally Posted by cheebamonkey
My guess is that this is because the dps cycle comes closest to an actual "cycle" at this value and then becomes more chaotic after that.
Since every spell is hasted by the same percentage in 2.4, the only constants are SWP and VT duration. What you simulated is a perfect player (lag 0, reaction time 0) trying to keep up his DoTs. The decrease in DPS is just due to the spell priorities resulting in decreased DoT uptime. Which should be less of an issue if you add in randomized lag+reaction time.
Also, I suggest using SWP>VT just for the sake of the simulation. If VT>SWP, SWP downtime can be as high as hasted 4.5 seconds (mind flay+VT), which probably happens most often at 170 haste. Clipping mind flays would also make the graph more linear.
#785SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â™¦ Kalman
Originally Posted by Tifi
Since every spell is hasted by the same percentage in 2.4, the only constants are SWP and VT duration. What you simulated is a perfect player (lag 0, reaction time 0) trying to keep up his DoTs. The decrease in DPS is just due to the spell priorities resulting in decreased DoT uptime. Which should be less of an issue if you add in randomized lag+reaction time.
Also, I suggest using SWP>VT just for the sake of the simulation. If VT>SWP, SWP downtime can be as high as hasted 4.5 seconds (mind flay+VT), which probably happens most often at 170 haste. Clipping mind flays would also make the graph more linear.
The simplest way to make the graph more linear is to use what most spriests do - we'll wait for a cooldown/refresh, rather than spend 3s flaying, if the wait will be short enough. I don't have programmatic ways to determine wait, but I simulated it across the lower haste range (HasteLAB graph of haste/wait relationship) and you can see there are pretty clear upper bounds, so a programmatic relation should be findable (as well as the bounding function).

The simplification of the math at work here is that average mind blast damage per second of cooldown is greater than swp or vt damage per second of uptime? For some reason I feel like I'm failing to take something into account here, and sort of want to make sure I understand the reasoning behind the decision and convince myself it's sound.
#789SourcePosted on<=2.0.0tedv
Originally Posted by Vandermonde
The simplification of the math at work here is that average mind blast damage per second of cooldown is greater than swp or vt damage per second of uptime? For some reason I feel like I'm failing to take something into account here, and sort of want to make sure I understand the reasoning behind the decision and convince myself it's sound.
Suppose you want to cast both Mind Blast and Shadow Word: Pain at the same time. In either case, you cast the other spell 1.5 seconds later. The question is... Which spell loses less damage from casting late? In the case of Mind Blast with a 6 second cooldown (effectively 7.5 with cast time), you lose 1.5 / 7.5 = 20% of a Mind Blast's damage. For Pain, all future ticks occur half a second later, so you lose half a tick, which is 1/16 (or 1/18 with 2T6).

20% of a mind blast is probably around 600 damage and half a pain tick is around 400 damage, so you lose less damage casting blast first and pain second.
#790SourcePosted on<=2.0.0cheebamonkey
Originally Posted by Vandermonde
The simplification of the math at work here is that average mind blast damage per second of cooldown is greater than swp or vt damage per second of uptime? For some reason I feel like I'm failing to take something into account here, and sort of want to make sure I understand the reasoning behind the decision and convince myself it's sound.
In my case what I'm doing so far is keeping Mind Flay as the benchmark and keeping the original spell priority then compairing (DamageX)/(CastTime+ExtraTime) with Mind Flays DPS. Basically if the dps of the other spell even with the extra time is greater than mind flays it waits and casts that spell instead of moving on to the next spell in the chain. In any case while I still have some tweeking to do with making sure it's giving proper dps numbers so far it apears as though there is a 1:1 ratio between SP and Haste and at this point it is likely it is at best a 1:1 ratio.
#791SourcePosted on<=2.0.0Xtoforas
I've been following this topic pretty closely and I'm excited about the addition of haste on 2.4 gear.

My question deals with primarily with how hast actually affects mindflay. Mindflay is regularly a 3 second channeled dot, correct? So will haste reduce the duration of the mindflay? E.g. With 10% haste reduction instead of getting a MF tick every second, would i get a MF tick every 0.9 seconds (making the entire channeling of the MF spell 2.7 seconds?). Additionally, with 20% reduction I would get a MF tick every 0.8 seconds?

So, assuming the above is correct, the MSD buff would effectively double my spell haste if I were to be at 20% reduction already, making a MF tick occur every 0.6 seconds and the entire cast complete at 1.8 seconds.

Does this make sense or do I have the concept of haste totally messed up?
#792SourcePosted on<=2.0.0cheebamonkey
except the equation for it is CastTime/(1+SpelllHaste/1570) meaning even with 1570 haste rating which is 100% haste your cast times are only 50% of their original speed.
#793SourcePosted on<=2.0.0Gonzeaux

[The Horseman's Signet Ring] is fantastic for the amount of effort required to obtain it. Of course, it won't be available again until October, assuming they don't change the Horseman's loot table sometime before then.

It's also great fun running that encounter. For a 5-man group, you could do the encounter 5 times in a single day. I ran it with my group and got the Signet on the second round, and got the [Witches Band] in the third try for my healing set, which is otherwise fairly lackluster.

#794SourcePosted on<=2.0.0cheebamonkey
I cleaned up my code a lot and made it choose to wait on MB and SWD cool downs when the overall damage would be higher. The code still sticks to a VT>SWP>MB>SWD>MF order in general but given the trend of the graph to get more linear each time I make it smarter I think it's pretty safe to say that the 1:1 ratio of SP to Haste is pretty accurate. Some disadvantages of my code right now is that dot's don't "tick," they are up front damage with cooldowns equal to the duration of the dot. Because of this it can't clip dots or MF. Unfortunately the more time steps I put in the longer it takes to simulate. Anyways here is the most recent graph I've come up with:

A workaround for mindflay clipping would be to have 3 versions of the spell, all of them would have the full mana cost but each version would be casted for 1/2/3 ticks.

Both start with 1000 spell damage, the top blue line represents increases in spell damage ranging from 1000-1500 total while the red line represents increases in spell haste running from 0-500.

#798SourcePosted on<=2.0.0Ntrails

#799SourcePosted on<=2.0.0Elerion
Originally Posted by Ntrails
Does that steepen the curve?
Yes. A higher initial value of +damage will increase the marginal value of haste, and vice versa.

The most valuable simulation would, as far as I can tell, show the slope (ie marginal return) of the +damage and +haste lines at chosen intercepts, which would be better represented in a table than by a graph.

Ugly example:

Spell damage\Haste     0           100           200           300           400

1200                0.5\0.49   0.51\0.48         etc

1300                0.5\0.51

1400                  etc

1500
Where x.x\x.x represents added dps from 1 additional damage\haste.

This would require some serious smoothing of the results obviously, since they are jagged. It won't show any small drop offs in the simulated material like above, but I firmly believe such dropoffs only exist in a theoretical vacuum. The only reason increased haste should ever lower dps is because it tricks the simulator/player into making suboptimal decisions.
Last edited by Elerion : Yesterday at 11:36 PM.
#800SourcePosted on<=2.0.0cheebamonkey
The return on Spell damage is constant always while the return on haste diminishes as you increase you haste. Basically:

%decrease is given by 1-1/(1+x/1570) which can be expanded to give 1-(1-x/1570+(x/1570)^2-...) or x/1570-(x/1570)^2. So your haste rating gets higher your return gets lower...not much but it does get lower.
#801SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Constie
Originally Posted by cheebamonkey
At this point I'm just wondering how long it'll take someone to make a mod that tells you which spell you should cast next. Because if we can model it mathematically then there is no reason why someone couldn't just make a mod to do it on the fly in game.
There actually already is one; http://files.wowace.com/Darkness/Darkness-r59814.zip


For the revamp, Balgoth, I'd suggest updating the "My guild is 5/5 Hyjal and 5/9 BT with absolutely no spell haste item drops, thus I have been unable to test anything." bit.
#802SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Amonra
Originally Posted by cheebamonkey
The return on Spell damage is constant always while the return on haste diminishes as you increase you haste. Basically:

%decrease is given by 1-1/(1+x/1570) which can be expanded to give 1-(1-x/1570+(x/1570)^2-...) or x/1570-(x/1570)^2. So your haste rating gets higher your return gets lower...not much but it does get lower.

That's not quite right - based on the formula every point of haste should add as much dps as the last.

The percentage increase in dps will get smaller each time, but that's the case with spell damage as well.


I think the main reason that haste is giving dimishing returns is down to the random latency added to each spell (assuming the simulations take this into account). An average latency of 0.15 seconds added to a 1.5 second spell is a smaller proportion than the same 0.15 seconds added to the hasted casting/GCD time.


A workaround for mindflay clipping would be to have 3 versions of the spell, all of them would have the full mana cost but each version would be casted for 1/2/3 ticks
Actually you would need to have a version being casted for 1.5/2/3 ticks because it isn't possible to cut the spell off less than halfway through due to GCD restraints. I have my doubts that cutting off after 1.5 ticks would ever be worthwhile because for an extra half second of chanelling, you get a full extra tick of damage.
#803SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Anderung
Mana is Meaningless
Hey Gang,

So while I was catching up on the past week of posts and such, I started thinking about my in-game experiences of late with +damage, +haste, virtual mana, etc...

If spell haste increases the channeling speed of Mind Flay (which it does), and DoT upkeep is the most mana intensive part of the casting cycle (especially maintaining VT to keep the mana buyback up)... there HAS to be a point where, during a standard casting cycle, enough +haste and +damage allows the priest to pump so much mana-cheap Mind Flay during a 15sec period that they cease to use mana. Where is this point?? How much +damage/+haste would you need?? In what mix?? Is that mix reachable??

And of course... if we're returning THAT much mana to the party, everyone in the party loves us.

And that's what it's all about.

The love.
-Anderung-
#804SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Omniro
Sorry, but I don't seem to get your idea. Spellhaste equaly raises the amount of mana spent and the amount of damage done. So spellhaste wouldn't possitivly affect your efficiancy.
As for the question on how much spelldmg one needs to get the same amount of mana back that one spent before: that's somewhere around ~3500 (if only using mindfly and asuming all of our own debuffs on the mob) and that, my friend is quiet unreachable at the moment
#805SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3cheebamonkey
Sorry, I wasn't thinking clearly last night, I showed that the cast time gets deminishing returns from haste however since CastTime =
BaseCastTime/(1+Haste/1570) and since DPS is given by BaseDamage/CastTime ---> DPS=(BaseDamage/BaseCastTime)(1+Haste/1570). So yes, DPS should increase linearly with haste. The rate for each spell though is based on the spells dps without haste, meaning as the base damage of your spell gets higher haste should get better.
#806SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Constie
Since VT returns 5%, the obvious thing to think is 20 DPM. However, if you account for other sources of mana regeneration (Meditation, MP5 gear, potions, Spellsurge, etc.) as well as the fact that your mana only ever needs to be (effectively) unlimited for the duration of a 10-15-minute fight, it's less than that. Yesterday, I killed Al'ar without using a single potion, and my group members loved me for going pretty much all out the whole fight, but I certainly don't come close to 3.5k +damage.

#808SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â™¦ Kalman
Originally Posted by Omniro
Sorry, but I don't seem to get your idea. Spellhaste equaly raises the amount of mana spent and the amount of damage done. So spellhaste wouldn't possitivly affect your efficiancy.
As for the question on how much spelldmg one needs to get the same amount of mana back that one spent before: that's somewhere around ~3500 (if only using mindfly and asuming all of our own debuffs on the mob) and that, my friend is quiet unreachable at the moment
Not true, because different spells have different efficiencies. Grasping wildly at numbers, if my VT will yield 3500 damage and my MF yields 2100, with MF costing 192 base mana, while VT costs 425 mana, the mana returned per cast is obviously very different. Since VT runtime is constant (once per 15 seconds regardless of spellhaste) while MF time decreases with haste, haste obviously increases the number of efficient spells you can fit inside of an inefficient spell. If VT is still net-negative while MF is net-positive mana, haste increases the ratio of MF to VT, raising your efficiency.

It's basically irrelevant, though.

cheebamonkey, again, I'd like to know if that graphic you posted was using 2.3 or 2.4 GCD rules.

#810SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Jonuts
Alright, I just used numbers that are halfway straight out of my ass for the sake of the fact that I forgot math. The chart given by Cheeba shows damage increase through adding only +damage or +haste. Using a bit of rounding, and maybe a couple guesses since the chart doesn't have lines, I came up with a starting DPS at 1000/0 to be 880. The end number at 1500/0 came up as 1100. (As I said, some rounding. Coming up with generalizations here, not trying to land on pluto.) At 1000/500, it looked to be about 1030.

Increasing +damage by 500 yeilded 220 DPS in this simulation, while increasing haste by 500 yeilded 150. Now my math is a bit crappy these days, but the calculator is still spot on. I'm coming up with 1 point of spell damage being equal to roughly 1.47 spell haste. Yes, these numbers aren't quite "best fit" lines, however I don't see the best fit from the given data being very far off. I'm sure someone can clean it up some, but it looks to me that you can trade spell damage for haste as long as the trade doesn't exceed 1 point of damage lost for every 1.5 points of haste. At least, this is my understanding. Anyone care to idiot check me/add in their own observations before I run off and increase my haste even more than I already am?

#811SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â™¦ Kalman
Originally Posted by cheebamonkey

Interesting. You're getting significantly less benefit from haste vs. spellpower than I was seeing.

The wait/nonwait issue's not that unusual. I'm reasonably certain that the metric you're using for how to trade off not casting may not be ideal - you aren't losing the whole cooldown time because sooner or later cooldown clashes will result in forced delay of MB cast. Try it with a fixed maximum wait time and see if you see similar patterns to my simulator?

An unrelated question: Ever since the dawn of time my initial cast sequence has been VT, SWP, (then VE but ignore that) etc. I did this in part to give the tank a little bit more time for extra aggro and I guess in part because i pull mobs that way.

I noticed another shadowpriest in my raid does it the other way round, I guess I lose out on 1.5 seconds of SW:P early on - but then VT is not applied until 3 seconds in.

I am not describing this well.

Either: 0 sec SW:P...1.5s-GCD....VTcast....3sec VT applied
Or my way 0sec cast VT 1.5 sec VT applied 1.6 sec SW:P applied.

Now, there is possible loss of VT mana the first method - since if any lag made VT apply at 3.05 sec it would not be up for the first tick.

Can anyone suggest some maths to tell me if I am correct or incorrect in procedure.

#818SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Originally Posted by cheebamonkey
Ok so sometimes I really do think I'm retarded. I had it additive for dps modifiers instead of multiplicative. I changed it around and now I'm getting numbers that agree with the spread sheet. Let me know if this is right:

(1.15*ShadowForm) (1 + .02*Darkness) (1 + .02*SW) (1.1*CoS) (1.05*Mis) (1 + .2*ImpSB)

If it is then this is the new graph which would mean haste and sp are almost exactly the same for us in 2.4:

http://img155.imageshack.us/img155/9...bandswdnd0.jpg
That looks more reasonable. Definitely matches the theorycrafting as well, putting 1 haste at roughly 1 damage. Of course damage looks very slightly better still (better DPM and the tradeoff is 12 spell damage versus 10 haste from epic gems). However, haste is definitely competitive enough that it's worth taking. In fact, the 6 spell damage, 5 haste orange gem might be a better choice if it fills socket bonuses. There's just one problem... We can't take yellow gem slots in reasonable quantities without losing mystical skyfire diamond.

In 2.4, [Mystical Skyfire Diamond] gives 320 haste rating for 6 seconds (according to the tooltip) and the proc rate is unchanged. Still has 45 second internal cooldown. This works out to one proc per minute, or an average of 32 bonus haste rating (worth roughly 32 spell damage).

Is there a viable metagem alternative to mystical skyfire that lets us use yellow slots for pyrestones? The new [Ember Skyfire Diamond] has a requirement we're guaranteed to hit and costs 18 spell damage. Each [Reckless Pyrestone] we use instead of [Runed Crimson Spinel] costs us 1 spell damage Each blue gem is a 6 spell damage loss, so we need to make up 18 + yellow slots + 6*blue slots in socket bonuses. This seems like it might not be possible even with the gear in sunwell, but maybe I'm missing some new pieces which are very heavy on yellow slots.

Summary: Haste is good but we're still chained to using Spinels.

Edit: Actually that should be a 16 spell damage cost because +2% int = +50 int = .5% crit = 11 crit rating which is roughly worth 2 spell damage.

#822SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3cheebamonkey
Originally Posted by Graf
Do the same graph without the rand() please, dunno if its on crit/lag or whatever, but it blurs the graph too much.
The choppiness of the line has more to do with random resists than with lag. Even over a 10,000 second simulation you are only seeing about 50 resists and if most of them land on MB or SWD you can see big changes in dps.

In 2.4, [Mystical Skyfire Diamond] gives 320 haste rating for 6 seconds (according to the tooltip) and the proc rate is unchanged. Still has 45 second internal cooldown. This works out to one proc per minute, or an average of 32 bonus haste rating (worth roughly 32 spell damage)
The other nice thing to consider on this is how many spells on average you can get in during the proc. If you are just chain casting MF and you have faster than 3 second MF's you'll effectively get 3 MF's worth of casting at the faster speed.
#823SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Originally Posted by cheebamonkey
The other nice thing to consider on this is how many spells on average you can get in during the proc. If you are just chain casting MF and you have faster than 3 second MF's you'll effectively get 3 MF's worth of casting at the faster speed.
It's not quite that simple. Lets say your standard flay is 2.75 seconds. With the proc up, your flay is now 2.28 seconds. The proc occurs at the start of the spell cast, meaning you have a full 2.75 second non-hasted flay. When it ends, you have 3.25 seconds left on the focus buff. That's enough for 2 hasted flays but not 3. So it will turn 5.5 seconds of cast time into 4.56 seconds, giving you 1 extra second of cast time. Effectively the proc was only worth a third of a mind flay in this case.

Of course if you proc focus after an instant cast spell, you'll have 4.625 seconds of time to cast spells with the hasted buff, so if you end up casting a mind flay at the very end of the window, you could end up fitting 8 seconds of non-focus hasted spells in 6.8 seconds of hasted time. This gets even better if focus procs at the end of mind blast or touch, because you get a full 6 seconds, plus however long your final mind flay takes.
#824SourcePosted on<=2.0.0Graf
Originally Posted by cheebamonkey
The choppiness of the line has more to do with random resists than with lag. Even over a 10,000 second simulation you are only seeing about 50 resists and if most of them land on MB or SWD you can see big changes in dps.
Then take out the resists for the sake of theory crafting. The usefullness of the graph is to see where the "slopes" are. So we have some "prime" haste values we can work towards.

+1dmg == +haste
Its true on an average, but certainly not at ever haste value, the graph should show some values where haste is less then 1 dmg and some where haste adds more then 1 dmg. Take out the choppiness and we get a much clearer view.

at +1dmg == +haste, its still much better to take DMG over haste, cause when fighting more then 1 mob, +dmg wins bigtime.
#825SourcePosted on<=2.0.0Asmo
You're missing one big thing with the new even more nerfed MSD, it lasts 4 seconds now not 6. So a lot of the time when it procs on a mindflay you're going to get only one 20% hasted spell out of it, 2 maybe if you clip the mindflay. The theorycrafting on shadowpriest.com came up with it at 19dmg which I think was maybe even a bit optimistic. So with the bad requirements to use it it's pretty questionable if it even will be better than the new 14dmg 2% int meta.

They really should reconsider this change imo since shadow priests now don't have a meta gem option that is anywhere near comparable in power to the crit metas pretty much every other class can use.
#826SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
Originally Posted by Asmo
You're missing one big thing with the new even more nerfed MSD, it lasts 4 seconds now not 6. So a lot of the time when it procs on a mindflay you're going to get only one 20% hasted spell out of it, 2 maybe if you clip the mindflay. The theorycrafting on shadowpriest.com came up with it at 19dmg which I think was maybe even a bit optimistic. So with the bad requirements to use it it's pretty questionable if it even will be better than the new 14dmg 2% int meta.
It's worth noting that the more haste you have, the better Mystical Skyfire is, because less of the proc is wasted on unhasted time. That is, if the buff lasts 4 seconds and you proc it on a mind flay when your flays take 3 seconds, you have 1 second to use it, so you only get one hasted spell. But if your mind flays are 2.5 seconds, you'll have 1.5 seconds of haste buff, so you can cast some instant cast spell (invoking a close to 1 second GCD) and the cast a hasted mind flay afterward, so you get two hasted spells.

Also, the spell data on wowhead definitely says 6 seconds: Spell Focus Trigger - Spells - World of Warcraft

Do we know if the tooltip is bugged or the buff? A 4 second duration will bring the value down to 24 spell damage guaranteed, and probably closer to 20 (but increasing towards 24 as you have more spell haste).
#827SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Amonra
Originally Posted by tedv
It's worth noting that the more haste you have, the better Mystical Skyfire is, because less of the proc is wasted on unhasted time. That is, if the buff lasts 4 seconds and you proc it on a mind flay when your flays take 3 seconds, you have 1 second to use it, so you only get one hasted spell. But if your mind flays are 2.5 seconds, you'll have 1.5 seconds of haste buff, so you can cast some instant cast spell (invoking a close to 1 second GCD) and the cast a hasted mind flay afterward, so you get two hasted spells.
Against that however, the more haste you have, the better +dmg becomes (relatively speaking). So the +14 dmg 2% int would be worth comparatively more.

I'm not sure which effect would be bigger, but it could be that the MSD becomes less useful as you get more haste.

One point to note is that if it pushes your haste rating above 780ish (i.e. reducing the GCD to 1 second), there will be very little additional benefit beyond that point. That would be a huge amount of haste however.

#831SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3cheebamonkey
Originally Posted by alkis
Is it possible to get a 3d graph?

x-axis: spell dmg 1200-2000
y-axis: haste rating 0-500
z-axis: dps

I think that would answer the more important questions: at what spell damage is 1 haste = 1 spell damage.
I've been meaning to do this for a while I just have been too preocupied doing other things with my computer like playing WoW. Each simulation of 500 steps takes about 5 minutes so doing a graph like that would take about 65 hours. It'll also be quite bumpy as most of these are, if I went for 100,000 seconds instead of 10,000, which I have done on a few occasions for looking at things in a bit more detail it would take 650 hours or about a month. However, since I think the linear relation ship is pretty well established the overall goal of gear should simply be to make your SP+Haste value be as high as possible, or perhaps a SP+.9*Haste.

No one said anything of the sort. That said, it looks to be ~1:1 for the first 200 or so haste, and converts quite favorably up to very high levels; using a 1:1 or 1:.9 approximation for quick evals is probably just fine.

The MB MF MF ideal is a bunch of shit, honestly. Not to mention the whole concept of a waitstate and clipped flays making MB MF MF less important that it's presented to be.

Looking at the itemization, generally you'd be trading 6 damage for 5 haste and a socket bonus... and the socket bonuses seem to be 3-5 damage in and of themselves. I think that haste/dmg gemming for socket bonuses will be quite common for spriests.

#844SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â—Š Kalman
Originally Posted by tedv
That's only true on items without blue sockets, which is almost none of them right now. Each blue sockets still trades you 6 damage for a socket bonus (2 damage) and either 7 stamina or 4 spirit. That seems never worth it to me. Even if the piece had two yellow and one blue socket for +5 damage, you have a net loss of 2 spell damage for 4 spirit or 7 stamina. The only blue socket you use is the T6 helm, because it's -1 damage for +7 stamina, or twice as good.

Are there enough pieces with only yellow or red sockets that you can gain the 6 to 10 spell damage loss by trading Mystical Skyfire Diamond for +14 spell damage, +2% int? I just don't see it.
Basically everything in Sunwell is blue socket free. T6 boots are the only exception, having a single blue socket in exchange for +2dmg. T6 wrist is R, T6 waist is Y.

Leggings of Calamity: RRY +5dmg
Pantaloons of Growing Strife: RYY +5dmg
Gloves of Tyri's Power: RY +4dmg
Helm of Arcane Purity: MR +5dmg
Robes of Ghostly Hatred: RRY +5dmg
Shoulderpads of Knowledge's Pursuit: RY +5dmg
Sunfire items are RRR and RR

The 6-10 damage loss vs. MSD is lowered by not having a worthwhile blue socket bonus anymore (once you replace T6 hat, of course), and having a number of worthwhile yellow bonuses. If we backgem as well, you can add:

Absolution Handguards (Y, +2 dmg bonus)

Now:

34dmg/5haste or 36 dmg is obvious.
22dmg/5haste or 24dmg is obvious.
5haste/8dmg or 12 dmg is probably 50/50.
27dmg/10haste or 36 dmg less so.

So out of our new items, they basically all do at least as well gemmed haste as damage, and most do better gemmed haste. Even at a fairly low haste valuation, 2-3 pieces of Sunwell loot will wipe out the benefit of MSD vs ESD; that's without accounting for the loss you take to gem a blue gem to activate MSD (1 damage, if you have T6 helm, which I'm assuming you do, 6 dmg if you don't).

#850SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3yawgmoth
DPS Simulator help plz
OK i'm trying to code my own dps simulator to see how spell haste will affect shadowpriest's spell rotation but i'm having some problems with it... Can anyone help with it? I'm a bit noob about this programming stuff...

Here it is:


#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

void globalcd(int vt, int swp, int swd, int mb, int ve, int t, int gcd)
// This function represents the time flow, we consider the time has passed equal to gcd everytime we call this function.
// vt,swp,swd,mb,ve values are spell cooldown counters (dot durations are considered cooldowns). Gcd is global cooldown.
// When a spell is NOT on cooldown, that means its cooldown counter is equal to a greater number than it's cooldown.
// t is time (miliseconds)
{
t=t+gcd;
swp=swp+gcd;
vt=vt+gcd;
ve=ve+gcd;
mb=mb+gcd;
swd=swd+gcd;
}

int main()
{
int vt, swp, swd, mb, ve, t, gcd, tmax, n_vt, n_swp, n_mb, n_ve, n_swd, n_mf, totalmanaspent, spellhasterating, spellhaste;
// n_vt represents how many times we cast v_nt in our spell rotation


t=0;
swp=vt=swd=mb=ve= 100000; // We set the initial values high, to represent no spell is on cooldown.
n_vt= n_swp= n_mb= n_ve= n_swd= n_mf= 0;
printf("Enter your spell haste rating\n");
scanf("%d",&spellhasterating);
spellhaste = spellhasterating / 15;
gcd = 1500 - spellhaste;
printf("How long is the combat? (In miliseconds)\n");
scanf("%d",&tmax);

while (t<=tmax);
{

if (vt>= 15000) // Casts VT if not on cd
{
globalcd(vt, swp, swd, mb, ve, t, gcd);
vt = 0;
n_vt ++;
}
else if (swp>=24000) // Casts SW: P
{
globalcd(vt, swp, swd, mb, ve, t, gcd);
swp = 0;
n_swp ++;
}

else if (ve>=60000) // Casts VE
{
globalcd(vt, swp, swd, mb, ve, t, gcd);
ve = 0;
n_ve ++;
}

else if (mb>=5500) // Casts MB
{
globalcd(vt, swp, swd, mb, ve, t, gcd);
mb = 0;
n_mb ++;
}

else if (swd>=12000) // Casts SW: D
{
globalcd(vt, swp, swd, mb, ve, t, gcd);
swd = 0;
n_swd ++;
}
else //Casts Mind Flay
{
globalcd(vt, swp, swd, mb, ve, t, gcd);
globalcd(vt, swp, swd, mb, ve, t, gcd);
n_mf ++;
}
}

totalmanaspent = (195*n_mf) + (382*n_mb) + (425*n_vt) + (52*n_ve) + (309*n_swd) + (575*n_swp);
printf("In your spell rotation; \n Number of VT casts = %d\n Number of SW: P casts = %d\n Number of MB casts = %d\n Number of SW: D casts = %d\n Number of VE casts = %d\n Number of MF casts = %d\n", n_vt,n_swp,n_mb,n_swd,n_ve,n_mf);
printf("Total mana spent = %d\n", totalmanaspent);
return 0;
}

Currently the output is this:
Enter your spellhaste rating:
286
How long is the combat (in miliseconds)?
360000

And that's it. It never gets to the loop part. Where is the problem?

Thanks all
#851SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â€¢ Polleke
This might not be the place for your C questions :p

You have placed a ; after your while loop. So the things within the block won't execute. After fixing that, it still won't work. This is because you are not modifying your variables with the globalcd() function. You are passing them, but not passing the modified values back. The lovely world of pointers comes here into play. Your globalcd decleration should look like:

void globalcd(int *vt, int *swp, int *swd, int *mb, int *ve, int *t, int gcd)

And calling the function like:

globalcd(&vt, &swp, &swd, &mb, &ve, &t, gcd);

And now modifying a variable within the globalcd function will look like:

*mb=*mb+gcd;

I suggest The C programming language SE to learn about pointers.

And if you do this all correctly you would end up with 100 haste and 360000 duration with an output like:

In your spell rotation;
 Number of VT casts = 20
 Number of SW: P casts = 13
 Number of MB casts = 40
 Number of SW: D casts = 21
 Number of VE casts = 6
 Number of MF casts = 71
Total mana spent = 51901
#852SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		lightstrike
I'm not sure this is the best place to discuss programming, and my eyes bleed when I read un-indented code in a non-fixed-width font... Anyway, ignoring your algorithm's flaws, and at first sight, I think this is why your loop never ends:
void globalcd(int vt, int swp, int swd, int mb, int ve, int t, int gcd);
You are passing the arguments by value, so anything you do with them in the implementation of that function will not alter the variables you pass, thus, your t never gets updated inside the loop, so the (t<tmax) condition is invariant.

Try this instead:
void globalcd(int &vt, int &swp, int &swd, int &mb, int &ve, int &t, int &gcd);
The results of your simulation will also be wrong, because of a few flaws in your algorithm, but that's another story, and I'm sure you can nail those down once you get the loop to end.
To avoid posting again things like this, I recommend you learn what a debugger is, how to use it, and why it's useful.

Also, please make use of the [code] tags when posting large amounts of code.
Last edited by lightstrike : 03/14/08 at 6:50 AM.
#853SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Samster
while (t<=tmax);
the semi-colon on the end of this line will stop your loop working. lightstrike is also correct - you need to be using pointers in this function.
#854SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3yawgmoth
Thanks for your help guys, the program works as intended now. I know this was a irrelevant topic, but i didn't know where to find people with both knowledge in c language and wow.
#855SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3tedv
I have a bunch of code improvement suggestions I almost sent in a PM, but I think there are enough programmers here that this would be generally useful.

A) Your haste formula is incorrect. At least use the 15.7 rating to haste percent conversion (and be careful with your reconversion of float to int). Also, haste is not subtractive, so GCD = 15000 - 10*haste_percent isn't correct. You want GCD = (int) (15000 / (1.0 + haste_percent * .01)).

B) You are passing around too much data to function calls. Create a structure to hold all your spell cooldowns and just pass in one pointer (or reference in C++) to that structure to the function that accrues time. It will be much faster. If you have access to C++, make inline the accrual function for extra speed.

C) The data structure makes you do too much arithmetic. Rather than increasing the cooldown on each of 6 spells, just increment the current point in time. Whenever you cast a spell, update the current timestamp and ONLY that spell's cooldown. Your loop will then check which of your spells have cooled down by the current time.

For example suppose it's time 5 and everything is cooled down (all cooldown values are <= 5). You cast mind blast and then update the current time to 5 + GCD = 6.5 and the mind blast cooldown to 5 + GCD + 5.5 seconds. Next loop step you check which spells have cooldowns before 6.5 seconds, and so on.

D) The Mind Flay call should use a time of 2*GCD rather than two calls, by the way

E) If you want useful results, you'll need support for lag and for logic that has the program wait for up to 1 second for thing like Mind Blast to cooldown rather than Mind Flay. The precise logic for this is really complicated to do correctly for all cooldowns, by the way, so if it just works for Mind Blast that's good enough.

If your do all of A-D, you'll have a guaranteed speed up of 6x, and probably more like 10x.
#856SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Gnolfo
I have been reading the discussion here about spell haste and wanted to chime in my thoughts about finding a conversion value between it and damage. Spellhaste improves DPS, there's no doubt, however it comes with several "but"s. But it depends on new optimal casting cycles. But it's more affected by latency. But there's times where it's worthless.

Casting cycle:

This isn't really news to anyone: the perceived, simulated DPS improvements spell haste gives versus the actual DPS improvements depend on how closely the new cycles are adhered to (whereas the benefits from spell damage/crit/hit are more direct). Simulation can find tweaks like, "In scenario X, you want to cast A before B; in scenario Y, B before A". These small improvements add up to significant advantages for spellhaste in terms of DPS output, which gives it a higher value of spell damage. However these small improvements can be very tricky to catch, whereas pre-2.4 haste was easy to figure out for spriests; it gets considerably more complex when the GCD shrinks as well. A human undergoing the same scenarios just isn't going to have the same precision in timing and immediate decision making to adhere to what's optimal on paper 100% of the time. Nobody can be expected to always make each one of those decisions correctly in realtime (maybe a future Spriest Spellhaste addon can help solve this). The difference this brings may be very marginal in the local scope, but certainly adds up over time, and will vary fight to fight, person to person, latency to latency. In the end it affects the DPS value we're applying to spellhaste as a stat.

Lag:

Simple enough. If a player with high latency had a 1000 DPS spell that was a 20 sec cast and a 1000 DPS spell with a 1.5 sec cast, the 20sec spell would perform better due to less time where the server's waiting for the next command to come through (recent changes have alleviated this is my understanding, but it is still there). Through the same concept, spell haste has you casting more often in a fight, so the effectiveness of your DPS varies more depending on lag.

Spell haste no good here:

When the player is busy moving from / being CC'd by a fight mechanic--which is fairly common--the value of spell haste effectively drops to nothing. Spelldamage keeps some of its worth during these times with dots ticking. How is that going to be accounted for when finding that 1 haste = X dmg conversion? We could start to look for amounts of "time unable to cast" as a metric, and now this is beginning to sound suspiciously like the problem holy priests face with calculating time in/out of the 5SR for finding a value for spirit. Would spell haste need a similar chart of % time spent casting for a given fight? I'd say so, as we're trying to equate it to +dmg, and we are sacrificing nominal amounts of +dmg for haste, and that +dmg lost could've been utilized through VT/SWP for the moments in fights where we can't cast and haste is doing nothing for us. Spirit is certainly a stat that has diverging opinions on its point-for-point worth (for holy priests that is), and spell haste is affected by a similar hard-to-pin-down variable of time spent casting/not casting. This says to me that at best it will be similar to spirit in terms of having an agreed-upon value.


In other words, I think we need to keep in mind that a spellhaste <==> spell damage value will never be precise. I think the best that can be agreed upon is "Spell haste is about equal to X-Y spell damage, but it depends". Spell haste is a stat that sees a variable amount of its potential "wasted" in practice, due to its benefits being far more susceptible (than spelldmg) to effects like lag and unavoidably non-ideal casting cycles. Then add in fight mechanics that can negate the effects of haste (but not so much that of +dmg) for certain %s of the fight, which is a very difficult value to pin down. We can definitely find a range for it, with the top end assuming a low% of time spent not casting and as close to the "ideal" cycle as possible, and the low end a larger % of time not casting and/or suboptimal cycles.

I don't mean to torpedo people's venture of finding a conversion, but just wanted to see if everyone was in agreement that spell haste is ultimately an "it depends" stat when it comes to assigning a value to it.
Last edited by Gnolfo : 03/14/08 at 1:31 PM.

I did follow a lot of the socket bonus things, because i tried to tally up the fact that (for instance the headpiece) if i aded 9 spl dmg and negated the socket bonus - i'd come out with less dmg. This way I get 11, vs 9 from the runed.

I do have the ruby slippers from karazhan, if i should use those over the shadow weave for a higher hit rating. Either the trinket or shoes...which one. i dont know.

Anyways there has been method to my maddness, but check out the profile and let me know what you think (if you would)

Take care
#858SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3â™¦ Kalman
Er. No, you're basically completely wrong.

The casting cycle does *not* become more complex. In fact, it arguably becomes easier to adhere to; I know one of my biggest problems is having the GCD not *quite* expired when my spell goes off, if I don't catch it, where I'll lose a half second to thinking I'm casting when in reality I was still under GCD. In 2.4, this issue basically goes away. The decisions are *not* hard, being essentially a chain of yes/no questions (VT up with >1.5? MB on CD? SWD on CD? SWP up? VT up with >2.5? MB off CD in next ~second? SWD off CD in next ~second? SWP out in next ~second? OK, mindflay - potentially clip flay, which means rerun that chain after 1 GCD). If you can't do this chain in your head, you're not a good shadow priest no matter how little haste you have. Haste does not change or complicate the chain; it changes the order of answers, but the chain remains accurate.

Lag is of minimal concern these days.

You also forgot to analyze points where spell haste is very good in your "no good here" analysis.

To over-simplify, take for example a fight with an "on" window of 15 seconds and an off window of 15 seconds. A player with zero haste gets 2 MBs off at best; a player with enough haste to reach 1.25s cast time (314 haste rating) gets 3 MBs off. While that's obviously an extreme example, it is also generally applicable to fights with phases - sometimes that haste will get you off one extra cooldown-controlled spell, which is usually more benefit than equivalent spelldamage (less true as phase length increases, of course).

So, overall, no, conversion is fine, just like all other stat conversions, as long as you apply intelligence to it. Sometimes it will be better than the conversion, sometimes worse, but overall the conversion is more or less accurate. It's not like it's the first stat with widely varying value (+hit on trash vs. bosses vs. bosses after 16% is already reached, for example).
#859SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Serrick
Originally Posted by Nakomi
I've read through a lot of the posts and the mathematical formulas.

The World of Warcraft Armory

Check me out (if you would)

And see maybe what i'm doing wrong.

Yes I realize my capped hit rating is less than desireable, but I can get it up to about 74-76... (Its a matter of switching out trinkets) I can put it back. I just didn't wanna lose either epic trinket, because the one i'm replacing it with is some "occulus eye" blue item

I did follow a lot of the socket bonus things, because i tried to tally up the fact that (for instance the headpiece) if i aded 9 spl dmg and negated the socket bonus - i'd come out with less dmg. This way I get 11, vs 9 from the runed.

I do have the ruby slippers from karazhan, if i should use those over the shadow weave for a higher hit rating. Either the trinket or shoes...which one. i dont know.

Anyways there has been method to my maddness, but check out the profile and let me know what you think (if you would)

Take care
You've made quite a few sub-optimal slotting, gemming, talent, and gearing choices. Without simply listing all of them, here are the main things you really need to improve on:

1. Where you can pick spelldamage in your gear, pick spelldamage. This applies to gems (spellcrit and intellect gems are useless in comparison to the gains you'd see from ignoring set bonus and going for spelldamage), enchants (bracers specifically, though investing in soulfrost would be a good idea too), and some of your choices in gear (you mention you have Occulus of the hidden eye, use that over the Skyguard trinket).

Since you're under the hit cap, gemming towards spellhit on some of those yellow slots wouldn't be a bad idea. Also note that spell penetration is almost completely useless in a PvE environment.

Try to shift almost all your gems to +9 damage when you can reach the hit cap without gemming for it. The only place it doesn't make sense to do is when picking up a socket bonus gives you the same amount of +damage.


2. Your talents could use a little cleanup. You want to have inner focus, pairing it up with pain when it's up is a decent gain in longevity for one point. Also, you really ought to max shadow reach. Dumping Imp VE is probably the easiest way to achieve both those goals.


3. Fill out your pants and boots with enchants. Some spellthread and even a cheap vitality (or boar's speed) will be easy ways to increase your damage and longevity.
Last edited by Serrick : 03/14/08 at 3:08 PM.
#860SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Ntrails
Originally Posted by Kalman

The casting cycle does *not* become more complex. In fact, it arguably becomes easier to adhere to; I know one of my biggest problems is having the GCD not *quite* expired when my spell goes off, if I don't catch it, where I'll lose a half second to thinking I'm casting when in reality I was still under GCD. In 2.4, this issue basically goes away. The decisions are *not* hard, being essentially a chain of yes/no questions (VT up with >1.5? MB on CD? SWD on CD? SWP up? VT up with >2.5? MB off CD in next ~second? SWD off CD in next ~second? SWP out in next ~second? OK, mindflay - potentially clip flay, which means rerun that chain after 1 GCD). If you can't do this chain in your head, you're not a good shadow priest no matter how little haste you have. Haste does not change or complicate the chain; it changes the order of answers, but the chain remains accurate.

In short, we carry on with the exact same set of decisions we made pre-haste, only faster. Seeing as I am usually at least one spell ahead of myself (I need to do VT next and then MB and SWD are both up... etc) this does not seem even slighty of trouble.


As I read the OP, you claim that a hasted SP's damage is more downgraded by periods of *silence* than a +damage SP's damage. (hope that makes sense. Hard to word neatly.)

I may not be the sharpest tool in the box, but DPS is DPS ==> If you have DPS of 2000 and stop casting for 4 seconds then you 'miss' 8000 damage. It could not matter less upon what this 2000 DPS is based. The reason we use dmg as the standard is because it translates to DPS. So does haste - though at a different rate. (i.e. we SHOULD say haste is worth 0.4 DPS and dmg worth 0.45DPS etc etc etc*.) Therefore I simply do not see what he said to be true.


However - to an extent this does apply to your 'on-value' logic. Because MB is such a boost to DPS it is more applicable than his example. Still not a factor that, imho, makes haste more valuable than the DPS graphs show.

*made up values for illustrative value.

#862SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3cheebamonkey
Originally Posted by Gnolfo
Text Wall

When 2.4 comes out the only people who will be able to actually make the choice between pure damage and spell haste will be people who aren't in sunwell, meaning exactly what we have now. It's been pretty well established not only through theory craft but though real examples that the haste builds do the same dps as the damage builds. For instance I run a 190 haste set right now and every week I do the same dps as the other two shadow priests in my guild who use pure damage builds provided we have similar groups.

In 2.4 if you are cutting edge which is what most of this haste talk has been geared towards you don't have that choice, if you want the max SP you can get you will have 200 haste at least. The question is do you want to go with 1400 sp and 400 haste or 1500 sp and 200 haste or whatever the actual numbers turn out to be. You can try to come up with perfect cycles for whatever you plan on using but as you've put even if there is a perfect cycle you won't be able to maintain it because of lag and resists. The simulations that I've done take both of these into account. DPS cycles are picked on an absolute 'which spell is best next' cycle with certain spells like VT set as a priority because of raid benifits. What it means is that if you are good enough at choosing your next spell you will get the results I'm showing. Maybe if you pick a better cycle you can even get better.

On mobile fights as Kalman says haste means you can get in more dps in the times you have to stand still. To support this I'll give you the examples of Void Reaver and Azgalor. On both fights I can perform exactly as good, and often better than pure damage builds, because my dots are ticking for perhaps 20 less and I'm getting in 2-3 more MF ticks in between having to move or in between silences.

Whether people like it or not haste is the wave of the future, you either except that and move on to how can I make it work best for me or you crash and burn like a hunter who still tries to fit aimshot into his rotation. If you can learn to think on the fly and and at very least pick the next best spell every time to maximize dps you can get the results I've posted earlier, if you can only do the simple cycle then you need to figure out which haste value will give you the highest values. If you choose the latter I'll give you a hint, shoot for 90 or 300 if possible and avoid 110 and 330.
